How is a Mag 7 stock hiding in plain sight? I was intrigued when I saw the subject, then you ruined it with META.

Gallium Nitride. No joke... Any company well positioned to begin manufacturing their chips using this modern technological advancement. Navitas is currently the only pure play in this field, but any company shifting to it will do. That and silicon carbide. Why? All the amazing things that google, meta and the rest of the magnificent 7 are working on is truly that... Amazing. Except for the fact that these advancements have surpassed the limit in which traditional silicon chips can supply power economically. There are almost no options out there for consumers to drive the next generation of GPUs. Silicon produces too much heat and is not at all efficient at delivering power while switching at high rates. Gallium Nitride will be the pick and shovel industry for the next generation of technology. At a third of the size of Silicon based PSUs, GaN can provide higher throughout 3x worth at lower heat. A smaller form factor means you can scale more in a data warehouse that is tight for space. Companies will save millions on cooling only. Electric vehicles will be able to charge in half the time or less without melting their connectors. Solar panels will be able to convert and store energy more efficiently increasing power collected and driving down cost. Its like the rest of the world created the fastest engines ever but the tire industry is just starting to develop the technology needed for those engines to go full speed. GaN is already showing up in many places including hundreds of smart phones and mobile charges. EVs and solar is moving towards it. I expect a lot of these companies to be acquired honestly but if youre excited about where GPUs and machine learning is going, keep an eye on its biggest handicap right now, and that is power consumption and our inability to deliver it. Were still in the euphoria stage of ML discovery but when it becomes fully integrated in our lives, it will drive the price up of these companies drastically.

The company ipod in June, is already profitable, was shorted heavily 85ish on no negative newsreportfiling etc. happened on July 23rd. And has failed to gain enough interest to really turn the price around since then, with one run that hit about 1.20ish. Price closed at 0.5758 Friday, and unfortunately they just got the notice that they need to regain compliance by March 24th, 2025 this date may be off a little bit, but it is definitely in March 2025. That being said, they are an ebikeescooteremotorcycle sales, rental, and repair company that has also branched out and started a delivery service centered in NYC. Why is it important that I mention NYC you might ask? Well because NYC is quite literally forcingaggressively incentivizing micromobility public transit adoption, actively trying to rid the city of traditional vehicles, semitrucks and even delivery vans, now beginning to implement lastmile delivery ebike delivery to their final destination from microhubs strategically placed throughout the city. It was a SPAC special purpose acquisition company where a pool of investors set out to find a company they thought could succeed with a large infusion of cash. They settled on what now is Navitas as the technology was just starting to be integrated commercially. The infusion was something over a billion dollars initially so they were cash rich. The officers of the company chose deferred shares as salary too to minimize the hit on cash reserves. They had been growing some 6070 YoY which kept the high valuation going. But this year, markets slowed and chip manufactures got hit hard, so they stalled on revenue growth adding concerns for a dilution in the short term. That seems possible for navitas but next year and forward is looking completely different. Since its new tech, they are inventing and innovating on the fly so it takes some time to deliver design wins like a year or two. Starting late this year and forward a lot of those design wins are coming to fruition. they are beginning their deliveries to AWS and Google data warehouses, converters to solar which was hit hard but on the up and up now, and more residential power devices like fridges, kitchen gadgets and laptop chargers. Whoever has the best IP here will be set up for the future. Looking forward to getting back to the 5060 YoY growth. Also much of Europe is starting to go solar and electric. The demand will be high for equipment that can provide the best power.

Infineon is a good company with cash to accelerate their designs and development. They had some recent breakthroughs to lower cost of producing GaN based chips. Navitas is the leader in IP though which makes them likely a buyout target in the future. They also are building out their silicon carbide arm as well for different type of power applications. I like either of these two.

They are but when you compare, really LLY should be getting grilled for the same thing, and the PBMs should be getting called to hearings as well. To me it seems like election year virtue signaling. You have a regulatory body asking why unregulated drug list pricing is so high. Its their job to add regulations so that theres a cap. Practically every other country does, we dont and politicians at this point choose not to. In the case of obesity and diabetes PBMs drive up list prices during negotiations so they can get favorable rebates. PBMs are middlemen that are also publicly traded like Cigna and CVS so they stand to lose more performance wise if they dont keep those prices high. NVO could slash prices and still keep a very healthy margin and potentially even sell more volume, but if they dont agree to PBM list prices they risk getting removed from their formularies which means lower sales all together and people not getting medication from NVO. Its one major factor not all that causes the price of diabetes and obesity medication to be so high in the US but low everywhere else.

HIMS is something Im a bit weary of. They have an oral medication thats only a shortterm treatment, and its not a compounded medication so it would be less effective than your traditional GLP1. Plus from what I understand its 2400 upfront for a year or something like 250400 per month. Being noncompounded its not as effective and not intended to be a long term treatment. So it doesnt work for everyone and I dont think its covered by insurance. In that regard it sounds like a niche market. It should be noted that none of what it sells is FDA approved. Not sure if this would really affect their oral medications. As for the GLP1 HIMS recently began offering, this would be compounded and can be a longer term treatment, but my understanding is theyre only allowed to sell this in the first place because theres a shortage right now. Ifwhen Nordisk ends its shortage on GLP1s I think the FDA at that point would demand HIMS to pull GLP1s from their shelves. So yes, they do have that loophole to sell without approval because of the shortages, but at the same time we dont even know if HIMS is violating patents or is unsafe and ineffective as far as their GLP1s go. Personally, Im not a fan of tossing someone desperate to lose weight who took a 10 minute survey and never talked to a doctor some drugs to inject into themselves. Dont know if when all is said and done FDA approved GLP1 makers or the FDA would be okay with this either so IMO its sounding real risky.

I like Quest protein bars and cookies. Theyre relatively expensive compared to brands like pure protein but very tasty. But a 20g protein bar could be too heavy for people who dont work out regularly. So, maybe the target audience is limited?

Why do you think distribution is a strong moat? The shelf space gives them an advantage against other start ups but is still tied to their own performance and bigger brands can still just substitute old products with new ones and be an immediate treat due to the low entry barrier. 23 of the category sales is through retail, so ecommerce is also not that important for snacksbars I would be really cautious about your assumption of a health conscious consumer. While I would agree that healthier eating is on the raise it doesnt mean plant based alternatives are also winning. Actually we know from trails at McDonalds and the evolution of plant based brands like Oatly that the demand might be limited. Simply Good Food does seem to be managed well as they are decreasing debt while increasing margins but for a growth stock the falling revenue growth is still a warning sign. Which seems to be reflected in the current stock performance. In general, I dont see a point in creating a 20 year strategy with single stocks. What might be a good stock now can be seen completely different in the 510 years because of bad management, macroeconomics, regulatory changes or consumer behavior shifts. If you believe in the category its probably more of an ETF or managed funds opportunity.

Whenever Im looking at a single stock investment, I always ask myself if I think the company will beat the passive part of my portfolio. Do you think this will beat the benchmarks lets say SPY or QQQ over the next 135 years? If so, why?

Quest choc. chip cookies are great, peanut butter are only ok but I prefer Think or Power Crunch for protein bars. Think brownie version are really dense so you can eat them slowly and get chew. Power Crunch are like sugar wafers so have an enjoyable crunch, crunch, crunch to them. Atkins Ive never tried, always too expensive. It seemed like they were marketing to keto people. If I were to research them for comparisons, I would look at the various sugar alcohols. Some things affect people differently maltitol, erythritol, chicory root etc. can make some peoples stomach churn.

Longterm exposure to a single stock is a romance with variance, and if the gods are on your side, youll end up very wealthy, potentially stinky wealthy even. But honestly, I dont have that level of risk tolerance.
From a first glance the companys growth is commendable. I have to look more into it. Especially that the EPS is below 2
EBITDA ?
Why this over Bellring BrandsBRBR?

That was me. But I did receive only one reply, a great one at that. Need to hear more voice of customer and voice of investor And your comment is similar to that one. It is hard to imagine SMPL a part of the oligopoly in Consumer Packaged Goods market
Agreed. They have cookies and chocolate chips, definitely no substitute for protein bar.

Distribution is the first aspect that a promising CPG startup has to secure to become a global player. Monster Coke and Celsius PepsiCo are just some examples on top of my mind. Of course you are right that the product has to sell. However, once the startup achieves the share of mind, described by Buffett, even the distribution cannot replace its products with alternatives. I am almost convinced that in CPG market, there are no longterm stocks with reasonable price. I will probably take your advice and invest in a fund.
This sure adds perspective. A company without moat wouldnt be able to beat them
Long term plays seem so obvious in retrospect. Not so obvious when forwardlooking

I check operating and net margins rather than EBITDA Operating Margin is solid at 17 TTM, 5 year average around 15.9. Packaged food industry average of 10.7. Net Margin 11.5 TTM, industry average of 6. EBITDA margins seems to be around 1820
My screener filters out high PE and high debt. Why do you think BRBR is better?

Ya i mean it was one of those I was looking at recently too. I think its a solid stowaway stock if that makes sense. Like if youre concerned with market valuations at the moment and want a slow moving protective asset vs. the overall market, this may be an option. There are so many stocks moving fast up north. This simply aint one. If youre interested in a growing brand that got wrecked and sorta relates to health id suggest celh. Their drinks are everywhere.. went crazy high and back to reality but it has the potential to 25x. Just a suggestion

My screener filters out high PE and high debt. Ah, okay. Why do you think BRBR is better? Wasnt thinking betterworse although BRBR has certainly performed well, was more curious given similar product category if you had any thoughts from that perspective on why one vs the other.
CELH is definitely a candidate I started to check recently. It is hard to find such companies in CPG market, I dont think there is a third option
Busted! I am not a customer in healthy nutrition market. I review financial performance and try to figure out if the company has a moat, investable etc.

replies.text: I dont get how a digital signing app is worth billions. Wish I thought of it first. Anyone can enlighten? Lol

heres the thing about a company like DocuSign. They are essential for all of the following services Legal Government Finance Their product is the one that most companies use when it comes to executing any contract. That means signing new employees, signing off on sales, etc. So realistically if they become the household name in that space, the floor for a company like DocuSign is massive.

I work in legal tech and I still do not understand why DocuSign is so highly valued. There is literally nothing super unique about their product that other businesses cant easily duplicate. What is their moat?

Its the kind of thing that maybe some private equity Vista? name buys out theres been a number of software buyouts in the last year or two of names that have cratered since 202021 and there was some talk of a DOCU buyout earlier this year but I dont find it compelling from the standpoint of the business itself.
Im surprised Salesforce hasnt bought them.
They have no moat in my opinion. Revenue could disappear real fast
As a client, I cant understand how this company is even worth 110 of whats valued now. Their solution is quite bad and has plenty of limitations. Id never invest in it.
Op made a mistake Docusign doesnt have 13 PE its more around 90 with 2025 estimate of 62. Looks like he looked at one time adjustments last earnings..
I tried to short it and lost 1k
Ive been shorting them on and off for years. They are doing nothing different than what other companies are offering for free. Adobe Sign is part of their bundle and is a better product imho
Isnt their MA10 and MA50 trending downwards , so can wait before buying the stock ?
The pe isnt 13 They earn alot in the last quarter and a tiny amount in previous quarters. It is some sort of one off
A PE is meaningless if its greatly influenced by onetime benefits or losses. Give the underlying PE.
90 of the companies questioning why this stock is overvalued or that it lacks a moat is the most obvious screaming buy signal ive ever seen. this sub is absolutely clueless
If Cathie Wood buy more of it then you know its speculation only.
And what does the company do? Digital signatures? No, thanks
There is absolutely no reason to invest in this. These companies are a dime a dozen

Its the standard across most industries that used to require wetink signatures. It is CFR compliant, auditable and holds up to legal scrutiny. They charge for seats and licensing across all of these markets. Im still dubious on buying before EA. Ive seen these drop with good earnings. May be a ya but what else ya got? Market response.
Op made a mistake Docusign doesnt have 13 PE its more around 90 with 2025 estimate of 62. Looks like he looked at one time adjustments last earnings..
They ask companies 5 for every single signature

They have over 2.5b in yearly revenue clearly theres a demand for their platform and its more than just an app, lets apply the same logic Uber is just an ride sharing app Adobe is just a photoshop app Zoom is just a video app Netflix is just a streaming app Instacart is just grocery app you can reduce many companies like this. Not saying theyre amazing businesses but its misleading to think of them in just that fashion as if its some service 3 engineers in a basement could run. btw the company I work at uses DocuSign, its more about the integrations with other systems including Salesforce, the facilitation of the contracts between internal and external parties, automation, auditability, those things are worth a lot to Enterprise companies without the headachecost of having to build or manage it internally. Even then like a lot of Enterprise SaaS it still requires some configurations and tweaks to get it tailored to your business.
My business uses Dropbox sign. Docusign seems geared toward large enterprise and is super expensive. But large enterprises probably like it for some reason
Thinking of it and executing it to a publicly listed company is two different things. They solved a real world problem and their solution saves people time and money. Thats why theyre successful
Its document management. Large corporations have millions of documents
My business uses docusign and I can assure you theyre worth is accurate. Its very expensive to use. If anyone has a suggestion for something cheaper while Im here... lmao

Imagine you are a lawfirm that charges your client 1200hour. Pen and paper are out of the questions. Using that would cost the clients 1200 more easily for contract. Using docusign would essentially reduce it to 0. For digital signing, would you use a proven tech like Docusign or some other small digisign providers? The thing that will make Docusign fail would be something like someone contest that they didnt sign this, and Docusign loses the record due to the technicality and the contract is voided. This would cause a mass migration.
Its more about the network effect of being a trusted certificate authority than the technology itself IMO
i dont understand this either. I use other digital signing software, and its just as easy. what makes docusign so special?
The problem is that they have no significant buy in. Switching to a different online signature provider would be rather easy compared to other parts of the office suite
Contracts for housinglegal is signed majority with Docusign in my area. Adobe pretty much doesnt exist.
I thought finance is managed through ERP software. Do they overlap? A better question can DOCU replace ERP in future?
It seems their moat is Switching Costs. Not easy to convert to alternatives like Adobe Sign. Still not enough to justify 12.5B MC, IMO

Their moat is the peace of minds. Lawyers are paid 2002000 per hour depending on the title. If they cant throw 20month to ensure all esigns are legal and correct, they are an idiot. That is their okayish moat being perceived as the market leader. Their competitors have even worse moats btw.... Esign isnt going away, and someone will win.
Especially if Salesforce wants to compete against Adobe Sign

Very few companies have a real moat. The only real moats are ones enforceable through a legal contract or government law. Look at Netflix and all the competition they received, doesnt stop them from being successful. Not having a moat isnt a reason to block yourself from investing.
What companies do have a moat?
Adobe e sign is out there too
What about the competition? Are switching costs high?
Do you have more info on the one time adjustments? Im trying to see why their net income was so high last quarter and cant find anything
what was your thesis to short it? did you expect DOCU to have net loss in Q2?
For Fiscal Year Ending 20240131 2024 Q4 169.22 For Twelve Months Period Ending 20240731 2025 Q2 14.83 For Quarter Ending 20240731 2025 Q2 14.83

Cannot be used for documentation that need a physical signature
40mo per user 7 per document, not per signature.

This explains it. Their signing workflow is platform company independent. E.g. lets say you have a need for 5 different companies to sign and each company has 5 layers of signer. Without DocuSign it may take you a lot of time and money. Some other companies also offer the same but may not be as good as DocuSign. But it should be more researched

No. Docusign is not revolutionary in any way. I believe they wont make it very far in the future. For example, the government of Portugal has a similar software that lets you digitally sign a document and that signature is cryptographically binded to your ID. This is peak for a signing software. And let me tell you this, if the shitty government of Portugal managed to pullthis out, Im pretty sure it wont be long before this is something uses in the entire EU and many other countries and then Docusign goes bye bye
The reason is Compliance

If everybody uses it it makes things much much easier. Say you want to make a deal with a different company if both of you already use DocuSign there is a lot less friction when inking the deal. Its the same as zoom for inter company meetings
I think it more businessready than other platforms e.g. security and it integrates better into business systems.
you dont know what ERP software is

MA, V, AAPL, MSFT, COST, AMZN, GOOG, META, NFLX, railroads, INTU, SPGI, ... There are a lot to pick from

I thought there is no moat, and the pe was unjustified, but thats more for a long term short so it was a bad call on my part
Anyone whos worked to gain broad legal acceptance of something new is dying laughing at the easy quantification of that. The computer code part isnt the hard part of what DOCU has achieved, imo.
Documentation that requires a physical signature is getting rarer by the year. In health care, lots of documents and orders are signed electronically these days.
True, there are some industries that have not turned yet thinking home titles but a ton have and docusign is getting the majority of the market.
No shit?? Sell it all to the ground now. Useless app.

Simply put ERP software often do not have e signing capabilities which honestly baffles me. Its such an easy way to build in native capabilities.
Adobe fumbled this bag so fucking hard. Cant execute for shit sadly. I doubt they can execute well.

But as a soft developer myself I can tell youd be incredibly surprised how ineffective most of the big companies are. The guys simply do not bother about changing unless theres a catalyst or prices keep increasing yearly. Also the few times Ive proposed switching this to better alternatives the expectations got too high with many leaders talking about investing block chain alternatives. Microsoft has the SharePoint esignature but its not quite like what DocuSign is used for primarily for signing contracts between third parties that most likely would not be at your SharePoint ecosystem. One tweak from Microsoft and they could build a rival software, the thing is most likely being the greedy bastards they are, they would charge something similar just enough to be at space and not to compete

There are a few government agencies that still require wet signatures, but most have switched.

replies.text: I would not buy Rivian unless I was trying to swing trade from something like 5 a share. I understand the product is good, but the cash burn is way too aggressive and the car industry is just very hard to succeed in. I would say the same thing about most other EV stocks. There are better opportunities for speculative investments in other sectors.
So everyone saying no ha??? So I guess Im in then

It was trading a 8.40 in April prior to the 1 billion dollar lifeline up to a total of 5 billion by VW for their joint venture. It is now trading at 11.17. This seems like a good entry point if you think the R2 will be a successful product. I picked up some shares the last few days but its still a gamble and you should treat it as such. There is no sensible reason to buy a Rivian with their low number of service centers, high repair costs, and high insurance costs... but damn, do they ever have a good looking product.
Until they get the Georgia plant going, Im staying away as far as possible. Output is too damn low for its valuation.

The way to profit from EV is not to buy Tesla or Rivian etc.. they have huge capital investments competition and have to take risks. The way to play is follow the classic picks and shovels strategy.. buy the supply chain players.. power semiconductors, lithium, copper, electrical connections, charging infrastructure, etc. electrification is a given... These companies will make money. Selling EV at loss that replaces ICE vehicles is not going to make you money as you are replacing one with another... Not necessarily increasing sales...

Just buy it. High risk but high reward. We all hold a few of these. Buy it and look at it after R12 and R13 numbers come out 2026. If its anything like the bump to profitability Tesla got look out. They are very busy selling everything they make. Look at the website store for what is available nationwide. I think they only have a few 3 or 4 R1S trimotors in the store. They are also busy building service centers and charging stations. As these numbers grow and people live closer to service centers the sales numbers will continue to grow. They have a unique product unlike anything on market now. They have also retooled the factory and make motors in house etc. so the cost per vehicle is going down to make. Lastly I own the stock and like it full disclosure.

Bought a small position earlier this year at 10.50 and sold after the Volkswagen news. Havent looked at it since then until now and saw its back around 11. Love the vehicle, company seems like headache though from everything Ive seenlooked at myself. What are they doing to fix their burn rate. The money from Volkswagen is nice but that doesnt solve their problem it just postpones it. Is there any evidence the cheaper Models will have higher margins? Thats their biggest issue. How do they fix it? Will fixing it make their product worse? Etc. Etc. Im happy to root from the sidelines and am rooting for the company but their seems like way easier ways to make money.

I live in a HCAOL and Im seeing more and more Rivians. They look great and I think they might be able to take some Tesla business. I bought a couple hundred shares on that possibility alone. We will see.

IMO, right now is too early. Even if they have a profitable grossmargin by Q4 with the R1 Gen2, theyll still bleed about 1Bquarter, based on their past financials. And thats going to be a long 56 quarters until the R2 starts production. And then you run the risk of R2 sales not meeting expectations.

They have a partnership with Amazon, there is currently more than 10,000 rivian trucks delivering for Amazon and more to come, they were partnered with Mercedes as well but rivian dropped that partnership themselves. Give this company 5 years and its gona dominate mark my words.

Management doesnt care about shareholders at all. Anyone objectively looking at the stock can see the ridiculously high cash burn rate, the shareholder dilution, and the ever increasing debt loads. Theyve missed virtually every metric they ever set and dont even have their performance compensation tied to company performance. Note that gross margin is still massively negative, meaning theyre selling their vehicles for less than the basic raw materials and labor to build the vehicles even cost something Tesla and other EV makers never did. Imo wait until they show a clear path to profitability before buying. This is a company that has the potential to thrive but in its current state the stock is just a piggy bank that the execs are using to increase their own wealth while they dilute and destroy shareholder value.

I think its possible in the next 510 years as self driving tech advance car ownership could change. Too much potential for major market dynamics shift. True self driving on open roads could make the concept of owning a car change. If you can pull it an app and have ANY car you want for however long you want and get rid of it immediately after really changes how people relate to cars and makes it possible for them to be much more expensive. Im not saying it will happen but its very much a possibility so Im staying away for now

Bought 100k worth at 13share. Its risky of course but the upside can be huge. My prediction is that there will be another bull run on EV and this will 10x. EV is way early and burning cash is normal when youre building manufacturing plants and cars from the ground up. They pass the eye test too...I see way more Rivians than anything other non Tesla EV

With Rivians stock dropping significantly since its IPO, People looking at the IPO price and how much its down since it should have never been at that price. They were lucky to go public at that valuation, but shareholders who piled into that bubble got obliterated. Looking forward, RIVN probably is one of the few smaller companies that went public in 202021 who will get through this period but I dont think thats ultimately as exciting as people think. Too many people still treating the EV theme like its the 202021 bubble and trying to pick the next Tesla. Meanwhile, a number of 202021 EV ipospac names are already 0s some of which are 0s for the second time. The automobile business with a couple of exceptions is not a great business I mean, again multiple EV companies that went public a few years ago already 0s and Tesla made everyone think it is, despite Musk frequently going on about what a difficult business it is over the years. So, can RIVN bounce? Sure. Is it going lower if there was a recession in the next couple years? Absolutely. Do I think it can be one of the few smaller names that ultimately gets through this period? Yes, but I think the market has gone back to the idea that automobiles are not a great business and people keep wanting them to be something they arent. So, I think RIVN could bounce on any good news, its going to be a tough hold through whenever the next recession is and on the other side of that will probably do fine on the upturn but I think people still expect too muchis it the next TSLA!?!?! from the theme.

I was a huge Tesla fan until Elon started behaving like Trump just a younger version and possibly a more deadlier version with his Space X and Twitter companies to influence the world. Excellent company. Still gaining ground. Takes time. Have you heard the ceo speak? Definitely worthwhile and I believe this will be a major contributor to the auto industry in the next 50 years.

In my area everyone wants a Rivian, I see them everywhere. Im putting in an order for one. I live in the Sillicon Valley so I might be in a tech bubble.

I do not know much about Rivian.. but as an investor for you to make money they have to sell a lot more vehicles at profit while investing in massive factories and competing with other players Instead I would bet on lithium miners like albamerle or sqm and other lithium lifecycle companies beyond miners. I heard battery might be commoditized .. so maybe battery recycling. Think what changes in the car architecture.. more motors more copper more high voltage electric lines and interconnects .. companies like molex amphenol comes to mind. Then semiconductors that focus on power conversions and controls like nxp infineon renesas will also win irrespective of who sells more EV. Then there are utility companies which should see more demand along with data centers. There is massive work in EV infrastructure and charging but again focus on the vendors and not necessarily blink or charge point. Along with ev.. there will be a shift to automation .. the players making the cameras lidar chips and software would make more profit than waymo Tesla or gm who are competing to bring the vehicles. It doesnt mean that Rivian or Tesla is a bad investment but its no longer a first mover environment... I have no idea of knowing if they will or will not but if I trust that EV is going to be the future.. then I would bet on the supply chain. Solar might be a big winner in EV . Not so much in data center case. Think ancillary issues... Charging time is still a problem... Land is limited... You want chargers in strategic location. Who has land that might become useless with ev chargers.. think the gas stations... So they will transition there with scope of commercial real estate developing. Else the grid will transition to micro grid with battery storage becoming more critical.

Besides as being pointed out they cannot even produce the vehicles profitably and it is not that close they are spending this year based on their own production numbers nearly seventy thousand dollars per vehicle sold to run the place. To turn around they first need to be profitable on their product but even if, and this is a big if, to pay the four billion a year they spend to run the place requires selling more vehicles per quarter than they sell now per year and clearing twenty thousand plus on each. That is how deep this hole is.

Honestly, for me, its both. For a company like VW, for example, to admit, they lose money on every bugatti veyron that rolled off the line. Its eh, because its a niche car for a niche price that only 0.5 of the worlds population has the capital to afford. So realistically, it isnt cutting into their bottom line as much as it sounds because VW still has audi and several other brands that are rebounding the loss from bugatti. But rivian is selling to the general public an EV that they claim is competitive to tesla, and announving that they are losing 32,000 per vehicle, which granted, from q4 23 losing 43k to now theyre reducing that number sure, but thats still per car world wide. replies.text: If you have the cash to buy the shares at the strike, it isnt a naked put. Its a cashsecured put.
Selling puts is like renting your money out. Collecting premiums. The goal usually is not to get assigned. But if you do get assigned feel free to sell covered calls on your new position.

This is really up to you. No scenario is better or worse without any idea of direction. If you sold a put for 100 and before the end of week it went to 200, you would be sad If you sold a put for 100 and before the end of week it went to 1, you would be sad Is the stock more likely to go up or down in the timeframe of your contract? If up, buy the shares and sell a covered call above whatever range you think its going to move, keep selling higher contracts. If down, sell the put, and keeping rolling it down or take assignment when you think the bottom is in. Or simply look at it as would I rather have some premium and no shares, or some shares and not miss out on a rally

If you want to own the stock, it usually makes the most sense to just buy the stock. If you think the stock is going up, youd rather have the shares then sell a put. And if you think the stock is going down, youd rather just wait to but instead of selling a put.

Either the stock will be above or below the strike at expiration. If its above, you keep the premium minus any commissions. If its below the strike, youll get assigned the shares, and your costbasis will be the strike price minus the premium received. Commissions will factor in as well.

Yes, as mentioned it is a cash secured put. So if the put expires in the money, the shares are put to you assigned at the strike price. If it expires out of the money, you simply collect the premium for selling the put.
can possibly blow up account if you are on wrong side of the road direction wise.
Thats a good way to look at it, thank!
Buying the stock and selling a covered call is exactly the same as just selling a put

You can blow up an account buying shares. Selling cash secured puts has the same risk profile as buying shares. I buy 100 shares of xyz and 20 dollars a share. The cost is 2000 dollars. Share price drops to 0 the next day. I sell cash secured puts at a 20 dollar strike price. Same thing happens I get assigned at functionally 0 the next day. It cost me 2000 to buy the shares lest the premium received. The risk profile is actually slightly better to the downside on cash secured puts than just buying shares. Selling naked puts can blow up an account, but CSPs are about the safest options strategy around minus covered calls.

Mostly, except one you have the shares, and the other you dont. I agree the premium received is essentially the same assuming you sell the same amount OTMATMITM. But buying 100 shares and selling a 105 call, and it rips to 110 is different than selling a 95 put and it rips to 110. One you have premium 500 the other one you have premium and not much else. The converse is also true one you lose more money, one you maybe dont. I will mostly agree that selling a 100 CSP and buying 100 shares and selling a 100 CC is basically the same depending on what the price is at. What I was trying to educate them on is in what ways they can be different as everyone who asks this question asks it in a way where the answer is theyre the same which doesnt really educate them on what the differences could be.
If you sell a weekly CSP for premium and the stock goes up 5 that week, youve missed out on 500 by not just simply buying the shares. So no...its not quite the same.

Theyre the same for the same strike price. In your example, buying 100 shares and selling a 105 call would have the exact same payout profile as selling a put at the 105 strike. Most people think of covered calls as something you do above the current price, and selling puts as something you do below the current price. In reality, you could choose any strike price for either one of them depending on how bullish of bearish you are. If hes really bullish for example and wanted to sell puts, he could sell a put 10 above the current price of the stock. Hed still get some premium because there would still be some extrinsic value baked in there, and he would still participate in any movement in the stock upwards until it reaches that 10 the same as buying the shares and selling a covered call 10 above.
Its exactly the same. Sell a put w 100 strike for 10. Buy 100 shares for 100 and sell a covered call for 10. Run through the potential scenarios there and tell me how theyre any different?

I wear some topoftheline hearing aids in both ears, and I fully intend to try out Apples solution. Mine cost me 5000 after the insurance pays their share, and theyre several years old now. The battery lasts a full week of daytime use, and programming is part of the service the doctor provides, so I cannot customize it. I do, however, have copies of all my hearing tests for the last 10 years, so I can see how it has changed and can extrapolate reasonably well. Plus, Apple claims theyll provide a hearing test feature. If Apple provides all those same frequencies, it would be truly game changing. The Airpods Pro 2 are ungainly and only last 6 hours, but for about 250 each I could afford to buy two pair and charge one while wearing the other pair, then swap out when theyre spent. Given culture the way it is today, I can get away with wearing them anywhere, too. Plus, listening to music on them would be a far better experience than anything my current hearing aids can do since they require a loop necklace antenna and buggy bluetooth sync to work today. That will be a huge win for Apple right there. Finally, I could easily build a set of microphones to feed into the Airpods. I work with Raspberry Pi and IoT all the time, so assembling and programming a microphone array would not take more than a month for me. I could build myself a custom necklace that would really amp up my hearing all around and allow me to program which air heard the result to custom effect. I cant wait to try it out! First of all, hearing aid thing is not ground breaking at all. It has been in the works in the industry for a couple of years, every single earphone company is working on it. Gn resound had something like this a year back. But why now? US FDA changed regulations around sharing aids sometime in 2019 or so, and they allowed hearing aid to be sold over the counter. This enabled consumer companies like Apple to roll this out. So, is the apple one any good? Not really. Its a gimmick. Why? Apple AirPods only last 67 hours with a single charge and continuous playback hearing aid feature is effectively continuous playback mode. This is not usable for most people. Medical grade hearing aids last 34 days with one battery. You dont want grandma worrying about charging her AirPods every 6 hours and sit down for an hour for it to charge without hearing. This is why traditional hearing aids last multiple days. This is a nothing burger. They already had the transparency mode, which passes through external sounds to the ear. Hearing Aid mode is basically amplifying it and playing it louder, with some additional minor challenges. If you are looking for Apple and health, this aint it. Apple HealthKit is more promising. More and more medical grade devices now integrate with Apple HealthKit and their fertility tracking etc is getting really really good. Recently, FDA allowed Dexcomm to sell their continuous glucose monitor directly to customers and dexcom is now working with Apple HealthKit giving Apple glucose data from users. This is a medical grade FDA cleared device used by millions of people who are diabeticpre diabetic . Source myself, an electrical engineer who used to design hearing aids for a living

ubamadesi Im not sure where youre trying to go with your comment, but Ill just say the following 1. If by bio business you mean biotechs as a whole, well nobody is ever going to be familiar with all of them, and each biotech has its own idiosyncracies and unique selling points. Therefore, we ALL need to read about bio business. Also, as far as getting familiar is concerned, asking questions here is actually part of getting familiar with the sector and learning more about it. Nobody has a monopoly on knowledge. 2 Big Pharma and biotechs are not the same thing. A financial win for a Biotech company may barely move the financial needle for a Big Pharma company thats worth multiples of billions, depending on the amount of sales of the drug. If a biotechs drug is not the only drug on the market for a given illness, the money made from that drugs market share will be limited, since the Total Addressable Market will be shared with the competing drugs. There are also drugs that most of the public who need them will never see, due to the unfortunate fact that those drugs are too expensive to be massproduced for the wider market. 3 A companys revenue is very different from its stock price action. Even when a drug is sold to the public, it isnt guaranteed to translate to significant stock price increase. If a biotechs stock price doesnt move much, then that biotech isnt attractive to private investors, even if it remains desirable for a big pharma company to invest in it.

replies.text: Look into the wheel option strategy. Use the cash obtained from your assigned soldcalls to then sell a cash secured put so you will actually be paid on the other side of the transaction to buy back into the stock if it falls in price again.
What if the stock shoots to 105? And your buy of 101.1 never executes? Chances are it wont work out like you want to.

You can also buy back the option and sell a new covered call at a higher strike price. The problem with selling and buying the stock back is youre missing out on long term capital gains. If the option on the last day is above your strike price you can buy it back at a loss but then sell another covered call at a higher strike price. You just have to have enough cash on hand because depending on how high the stock goes it can be expensive to buy back.
Why does everyone always downvote legitimate questions its so annoying

Thats why I want it to open the position at 101.10 immediately upon selling, when its still at 101.00. These numbers are examples, I could choose to create a bigger spread to avoid having the price run away before my order executes.

This is what I was describing, I think. I wouldnt really be missing out on the capital gains because I would be buying back the stock at approximately the same price I sold it at. So if I bought it for 10k, sold it at 11k and then immediately bought it back at 10.95k I would be losing .05 there but still making .95 on the initial investment. Plus by selling the covered calls I could make an additional whatever amount. The trick would be to buy it back quickly enough to not let the price run away from me before the buy could execute, if its on a steep bullish run. I suppose with smaller volumes this would be a more feasible tactic because I could fill the order more quickly.
deleted

Calls dont get exercised until they expire. So youd have to buy prematurely before you know for sure youll lose the shares. So what if you buy 100 more at 101 and then on expiration it drops to 90? Now you have 200 shares worth 90 each
I meant long term capital gains tax treatment. Youll pay more on the gains in taxes if you buy and sell them constantly.
So why is it bad to ask questions? Jfc Ignorance is only condemnable when the party in question has no interest in learning.

Calls can be executed on or before the expiry date, in the example Im assuming the strike price is met before the expiration. So if my strike price is met I want my exchange platform to immediately open and hopefully fill another order to buy back those same stocks at a slightly higher price before the market price gets away from me.
deleted

You are right they can be exercised prior but you cant force it. And I am telling in you it wont. More profit can be made by selling the option instead. Rarely are they exercised prior to expiration, only people who dont know what they are doing. The whole point of options is leverage, when its exercised its lost. You can do whatever you want. I am saying your plan wont work. If it did everyone would be doing this.
Its unlikely the option will be exercised. It could, but as the other person said, the option buyer would make more by selling the contract. So the buyer likely wouldnt.
Not trying to argue with anyone, Im stating my understanding of the situation so that people can point out errors. My bad if I came off as a smartass

replies.text: You dont see it when you look at the revenue, but UpWorks growth has been declining and pretty much has come to a halt. Gross services volume is basically the same as it was a year ago. Revenue is only up because they keep increasing the take rate. 19 of what the clients pay now goes to UpWork. Their revenue guidance for Q3 is less than what they made in Q2. So they might enter a phase of negative growth now. Caused by declining usage which cannot be offset by further increasing the take rate. They keep focussing on enterprise deals and neglect the marketplace experience. Although the marketplace is the 6x bigger business. Clients who use the marketplace still get 3 ! invoices and receipts per week ! even if they just work with one freelancer. Who wouldnt want to add 19 to their freelancer cost and the hassle to add 12 documents per month to their tax paperwork? TlDr They focus on their sales team, neglect the product, make it more and more expensive, usage growth declines. They still have a great starting point as the market leader in work marketplaces. But unless they change the approach, I think nothing will come out of it. If the business slips away, my hope is that a new, more product oriented CEO will come into play.
Assymetric to the downside.
Ive been on Upwork for years It is straight ass these days

Thank you for sharing your thoughts. I do agree that there is still work to do, however, the take rate is much much lower compared to Fiverr. I do think the invoicing part can be improved, I know theres a giant project in regards to the VAT calculation.

Im not saying the increase in take rate is necessarily bad. But it is also not what can make up for a decline in users in the long term. Fiverrs market cap is 30 smaller than UpWorks. So it is not a proven way forward that can be a role model for UpWork. Also their business is different. Average spent per buyer is 4x smaller on Fiverr compared to UpWork. When you commission a onetime job like a logo, it doesnt matter if you pay 100 or 130. That wont make you take the job off the platform. But when you work with a freelancer on a constant basis, you start to think about why you pay UpWork every month too. Because the only thing you get for it is the invoicing. And when that invoicing is done super badly 12 monthly documents instead of 1, 4 monthly payments instead of 1 you will think hard if you really want to continue using that service.

In my opinion, UpWork is there not only to connect the freelancer with the client but also to provide trust. it ensures that if the work gets done, the freelancer gets paid. In case of any disputes, an UpWork representative steps in. Taking a contract outside of UpWork is against their terms and conditions unless the fee is paid. Yes, clientsfreelancers can agree to continue working outside of the platform. However, if theres a dispute at any point in time, one party will be unsatisfied. In addition, both parties are back to square one, the client needs to find a new freelancer, and the freelancer needs to find a new client.

True. They offer more than just invoicing. Still the invoicing is done badly and that hurts a lot. Im not sure the other services make up for it. And currently the numbers make it seem that the concept is not working. Gross services volume was about 4B in 2022, about 4B in 2023 and might be even lower this year. Is there reason to expect that this stagnationdecline will stop and turn into growth again?

I focus on the long run, and there I expect Increase in the number of freelancers Demand for freelancers to increase UpWork has reported an increase in enterprise clients. This isnt much reflected in the revenue, and I have a feeling this is due to the terms offered. I wouldnt be surprised if they have a free trial for a certain period, that doesnt generate any significant revenue for UpWork in the short run.

Where can we see that the number of freelancers and the demand for freelancers are increasing? On UpWork, there have been 872K active clients in Q1 and 868K in Q2. Thats a decline. I dont see that they reported an increase in enterprise clients. Where can I find that info? All I see in the investor presentation is enterprise revenue. And that also declined. From 26.6M in Q1 to 26.3M in Q2. Despite them spending 47M on sales and marketing in Q2.

The active clients is an important metric. However, comparing Q2 vs. Q1 is misleading due to holidays. Every year, there is decline in Q2 vs Q1. Instead, compare it vs. Q2 the previous year. The enterprise number was mentioned in the earnings call, and is also in the 10Q report. Lastly, the sales and marketing is decreasing over time allowing for higher margins. This is not only for the enterprise clients, but for all.

I dont see the number of enterprise clients in any of their documents. What is it? Maybe you are referring to their number for new enterprise clients? That does not tell us if the overall number is increasing or decreasing.

Yes, indeed, the new enterprise clients. This number in Q2 is higher than in Q1. However, I do not focus too much on this, given that the size of the enterprise clients isnt disclosed. This is why I find the active clients a more relevant number.

So the numbers tell a clear story, right? Usage growth has died down to zero. As seen in gross services volume and active users. And with the guidance of 6 revenue for Q3, it stands to be expected that usage will start shrinking now. Despite over a hundred million Dollars spent on sales and marketing per year. My interpretation UpWorks service is good at the beginning of the user journey. To match buyers and sellers. But then it becomes a chore. Because of the weekly invoice cycle and the separate invoicing from sellers and UpWork. That makes it an 8x worse solution than direct seller to buyer invoices. UpWork gained a massive amount of users during covid. And now those users abandon the service. Its a long way down to precovid levels. It can make the business decline for years. On the upside, UpWork might have the potential to become as big as the other market place leaders. Amazon, Uber, Booking, AirBnB, Shopify etc are all orders of magnitude larger than UpWork and I dont see a reason the leading work market place shouldnt become as big as those. But I think that would require a shift in the way UpWork is run. As the current approach to growth is not working. As can be seen in the numbers.

I am not sure if the invoicing would change, and to what extent. If you are a freelancer, it is good to be paid weekly instead of monthly. As for the user growth, it isnt actually declining. The of active clients is growing. Last year, they announced a change in their fee structure. It used to be multitier 20, then 10, then 5. So, the larger the contract, the lower the fee UpWork takes. The new structure is a flat 10 fee for all. I do think some contracts were taken outside of UpWork, which led to a reduction in the average spend per client which is reflected in the Gross service volume decline. I do think this is temporary, as with any price increase decision made.

The 0.46 in active clients they reported in 2024Q2 is not active clients in that quarter. But in the last 12 months. So I dont see a reason to think that is a seasonal effect. In 2023Q2 it was 0.6. In 2022Q2 it was 1.77. So basically what the number tells us is that they lost more clients in 2024Q2 than they won in 2023Q2. Still, the 6 active clients YoY look kinda good, so if those would be the only numbers we have QoQ and YoY, I would say I dont know what to think. Lets wait until next quarter. But we also have the guidance of 6 in revenue QoQ. The worst guidance in the history of UpWork. And they explain it with negative trends in the topoffunnel which could mean active clients or spent per client I think and expect it to continue We did see those trends get slightly worse in June and July And they talk about working on anticircumvention efforts in the call. You can find it in the transcript. Which should mean they will try to stop buyers and sellers from leaving the platform once they have found each other. Why would they have to do that if their users wanted to use the invoicing service they provide? The users dont want it. I dont think you can grow a business by saying We have a good service and a bad service. We give you a good service for a few days and then well force you to use our bad service forever.

You cant conclude that their revenue will probably drop even more based simply on retail pharmacy closing underperforming locations. It makes no sense to compare a cyclical sector like banking to healthcare. Consumer stocks trading at high teens PEs need a solid growth story to justify their valuations, and we have seen how quickly they can fall if that growth story comes into question. A single digit PE like CVS is much less demanding. The question for the stock is how successful they will be at recovering their margins, if they can, then the valuation will jump, and investors will get a substantial dividend while they wait.

replies.text: Index funds is best for 90 of people especially you that are new. Once you learn a bit dip your toes with 520 of your capital
Dont dump 700k on intel

Id suggest making a goal of investing 100,000 in a low cost index fund like VOO. Take that time to watch the market and learn the trendshow the market works. After you accumulate 100k in index funds you have enough experience in the market to start investing in individual stocks if you choose to but never touch your 100k in index funds. Make that your foundation.
type boglehead in the reddit main... start there readlisten to those audiobooks then readlisten ok its boring.... but the info is gold stocks for the long run start slow and small

Put your money in the most boring possible shit you can think of ETFs, MMFs, high yield savings. Thats investing. Now you can then take some of your net liquid say 10 and put it into your trading jar. This is your gamble money. Day trading is gambling no matter how many people here will tell you otherwise. Youre not a whale so you certainly have no power whatsoever to influent a stock in any significant manner.

The best way to start and learn about the market is to just yolo into some options and lose 90 of your initial investment, so that you are motivated to learn as much as you can to regain that initial investment. Once you did that, you can earn yourself a pretty penny. Jk. Dont do that. Start with index funds and leave your fingers of anything else, until you have watched the market for a while and understand its tides.
You can start here.
Have an investment strategy first invest in that manner and reevaluate your strategy when needed. Suggest you do Roth IRA given your age there is great runway to make that a huge hill of cash.
Be good, really good. Or buy VOO without illusions to start being profitable right away.
Wait until 2025.
VTSAX and chill

SP500 is a solid bet for a longterm investment. Youre basically betting on the US economically, and its less risky than betting on a handful of individual companies like Google, Apple, Amazon, Meta, Telsa etc.
Buy GOOGL

Spread your money amongst different index funds, especially Vanguard funds. Invest in blue chip mutual fund and dividend paying index funds. I know the usual rule of thumb is to have some money in bonds to act as a cushion, but you have age on your side and I would suggest you fully invest in stocks, and as others have mentioned here, index funds!

Yer I have an index fund, its an addition to my pension, so is for the long term, they indeed have a role. But I will disagree with others and say there is still a role for stock picking, but education and lots of it is needed, not just on economics but also the history of stock market hysteria, to make sure you dont get sucked into following the crowd.

I disagree with the people saying to solely focus on sp index fund like VOO. Sure, that can and should be part of your portfolio, but an early 20 year old should take on more risk and buy some bluechip stocks of great companies as well. Examples of the types of companies Im referring to are Amazon, Microsoft, Google, Waste Management and other well established large cap companies. You should select your favorites and buy shares on a reoccurring basis. I buy my favorite stocks every week for past 20 years.
Well , tomorrow is gonna be a bloodbath so buy when it goes sideways. You will likely make money if you do this snd hold
Youve chosen a good time if you wait a week or two and see how the market evens out D

Werent GDP and wages also growing at about the same rate in 2007 as they are now? 2007 Leading up to the Great Recession, the U.S. economy saw moderate growth. In 2007, GDP growth was about 1.9 according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis BEA. Recent Years 2023 GDP growth has varied in recent years due to the impact of the COVID19 pandemic and subsequent recovery. For example, in 2021, GDP grew by about 5.7, driven by recovery from the pandemic, but this growth rate has moderated since then, with GDP growth in 2023 estimated to be around 2 to 2.5. 2007 Wage growth was relatively stagnant before the recession. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics BLS, real wage growth was minimal, with nominal wages increasing modestly but often outpaced by inflation. GDP Growth The growth rate of GDP in 2007 was lower compared to some recent years, especially during the postpandemic recovery. However, recent growth rates are beginning to resemble the moderate growth seen in 2007 as the economy stabilizes. Wage Growth Real wage growth has been more pronounced recently due to labor market pressures, but inflation has also been higher, which complicates direct comparisons. In 2007, wage growth was weaker, with stagnant real wages being a concern leading up to the recession. Recent Years 2023 Wage growth has been more dynamic in recent years, partly due to labor shortages and inflation pressures. In 2022, nominal wages increased by about 5 on average, though real wage growth adjusted for inflation has been mixed. Some quarters saw real wage declines due to high inflation, while other periods showed modest real gains. With all due respect, since youre 22, you werent alive during 9899. While that doesnt mean you can learn from history, Im not sure thats the best approach. Ive read some studies that say you should just jump all in immediately but I wouldnt feel comfortable doing that. My only advice would be to do what youre comfortable in as long as you have a plan to grow the money. Generally stocks, especially at your age.

The problem with waiting for a downturn is that most of the time when the downturn occurs the market has already risen so much that the downturn is still far higher sitting in cash. Look at what happened last early August the market went down but just to the levels of the spring of the same year. The 2022 downturn was still higher than the market had been before 2021. That couple of months in spring 2020 after COVID is the only recent downturn in recent history where being in cash before would have been smart. But who could have predicted that?
Do what makes you sleep easier at night. Youre probably smarter than everyone on here already.
DCA

Personally, at 22, you need to flip the narrative from Im scared of a market downturn to I am scared to miss the best performing days of the SP500. Missing the best 10 trading days of the SP500 results in a 54 less gain over the last 29 years. Market crashes at your age are a gift to build wealth. I wish I had a cost basis a 9899 values. Ill bet my fucking house that you will not even think about the stock market when its down 19, let fucking alone when its down 30.

You are young and it seems like you have a great head on your shoulders already. Because of that, DCA your funds. We have been waiting for a downturn for years and still hasnt happened. If the market goes up another 1520, and drops only 10, you still lost out on those gains not to mention it may not drop. If it does sooner, so be it, , thats the point of DCAing. Time in the market is better than timing the market and you my friend are way ahead of the game. If you are really worried, see a financial advisor and have them create a proper portfolio to start

If you just want it to sit around and grow for decades Id definitely do stocksETFs sooner rather than later. You are 22 and have plenty of time to recover from whatever happens. That said, if the 2 options for you are DCA or wait for a downturn, I would DCA. Could there be better ways to maximize returns, sure, but sleeping better has some value too I suppose.
DCA

Man, first off, kudos to you for being so thoughtful about your investments at 22. Youre already ahead of the game just by being aware of things like valuations, AI hype, and macro trends. I get where youre coming from with the fear of buying at the topits a valid concern, especially with how things feel right now. But the truth is, trying to time the market perfectly is insanely hard, even for professionals. A lot of people sat on the sidelines waiting for a crash after 2020, and missed huge gains. One approach I like is a hybrid of your options, continue dollar cost averaging DCA, but maybe adjust the amount based on market conditions. For example, if the market does drop, you can accelerate your buys. On the flip side, when things feel overheated, keep it slow and steady, like you said with 20kyear. This way, youre not sitting on the sidelines forever, but also not dumping everything in at once. I also think trimming your SPYQQQ positions isnt a bad call if it aligns with your risk tolerance. Maybe shift a bit more into value stocks, bonds, or even international ETFs. That way, youre a little more diversified if a correction or downturn happens. IJust remember that, while recessions are inevitable, time in the market usually beats trying to perfectly predict the timing.

But the market now and leave it alone for decades. You have so much time on your hands, even if we have a recession next year over the long term the market will be so much higher than today. Worrying about next year is the wrong perspective for equity investing. If you think things are too pricey but some dividend funds or something less tech heavy... but you really should just buy the market.

There was a dip in august, i would lump sum and continue to dca. More money is lost by waiting on the sideline than by getting in on the wrong moment. replies.text: Im a little baffled about how capital gains works out when Im trading with IRA assets. There is no concept of capital gains in an IRA. Just money in and money out.

For Qualified money retirement accounts the transaction of interest is leaving the account. ANYTHING that happens inside the account is taxdeferred. Trade as much as you want. The caveat, though, is dont fuck around too much with the money you plan to live the rest of your life on!
There are none. When you take money out of a traditional IRA its taxed as income. There are no taxes on withdrawals from Roth accounts as you already paid the tax on that money.

If you gamble the money in your traditional IRA and win big, you will be paying taxes on it. If you contribute to a ROTH IRA instead, you will lose tax benefits in that year. But if by some crazy luck your aggressive investments turn into millions of dollars, you will not owe any taxes because with a ROTH IRA you essentially pay the taxes ahead of time on what is likely to be a much smaller amount.
What kind of IRA?
Mostly agree, but there is a difference between contributions and gains in a Roth IRA. They have different withdrawal rules.
Fortunately Schwab wont let me trade options within my IRA Thanks for the info!

Thats crazy. I run diagonal options strategies, which are a slow and steady, predictable process with a carefully managed risk profile. They are resilient to even highly unusual, large market changes. They require some initial capital to invest in protective contracts, which safeguard short positions. Are you saying that if I invested the initial capital, posttax, into a Roth IRA, I could run my options scheme taxfree, with the caveat being that I would have to wait until my 5912th birthday to withdraw?
My IRA is the only place I trade because there arent any tax consequences. My regular brokerage is much larger and is almost all ETFs that I dont trade.

Current tax consequence is zero, it just adds to the cash and value of the IRA. When you take distributions, then you have a taxable event. Distributions from the IRA are always ordinary income, doesnt matter the composition contributions, gains, losses, dividends, when you have gains losses, etc. outside of this, such as a brokerage account, you get preferential treatment with the capital gains rate. Hence, I am not a fan of loading up on IRA funds like everyone seems to like to do. But whatever is in the IRA is in the IRA and nothing happens.
In case you didnt know, thats not universal. I used to trade options in my IRA. Worked out for me, but I left the casino after a couple wins and Im not going back.

Yes, with some caveats.. there are some rules and requirements for a Roth IRA Contributions You can contribute posttax dollars up to 6,500 per year 7,500 if youre 50 or older. Income limits apply single filers with a MAGI under 138,000 can contribute the full amount phaseout begins at 138,000, and contributions stop at 153,000. For married filing jointly, those numbers go up to 218,000 228,000. Withdrawals Contributions can be withdrawn anytime taxfree. Earnings are taxfree as long as youre 59 12 or older and the account has been open for 5 years the 5year rule. Investment Flexibility You can invest in stocks, bonds, ETFs, and even options with limitations. No margin or short selling is allowed, but you can buy options like puts. No naked calls. Tax Benefits Since you contribute posttax dollars, qualified withdrawals after 59 12 and 5 years are 100 taxfree, including all investment gains.
Interesting, the same general idea occurred to me.

I am not a fan of loading up on IRA funds Where did that come from? Ill tell you for DECADES, the conventional wisdom on paying taxes is defer, defer, DEFER. Pay them as late as you can, with inflationreduced dollars. Thats one of the pillars underlying the whole concept of taxqualified retirement accounts. Yeah, distributions from your IRA are always ordinary income, as you said, but dont forget that ordinary income tax brackets are progressive. When you start withdrawing it, some is taxed at 0, some is taxed at 10, some is taxed at 12, some is taxed at 22, etc. Paying taxes today is at your FULL MARGINAL tax rate. Its not as blackandwhite as you may think.

Well you do what you want, but, if I want to utilize my money, and not work forever, what is the efficient way to draw my money? Try to SEPP 72t the account? Interest rates impact that ability and may not be the most beneficial, and I would likely need a significant amount of funds to meet my budget in a low rate environment than I may have assumed otherwise have seen this impact first hand. Plus ordinary income rates on all of it vs. preferential capital gains and qualified dividend rates for a significant portion of it? Ill take the preferential rates. Im all for and will take some Roth dollars and pay my pittance currently, but why would I load up and defer for all those years so that I get it in the shorts on the back end at ordinary income rates? I value flexibility in my ability to use my dollars more than anything else. I lose that flexibility when I shovel funds into the IRA. Im not going to let tax dictate what I want to do, and can maneuver to a place that I am comfortable with the consequence. I also dont have forced RMDs like with an IRA, I get basis setupup to my kid for any inheritance, I dont have a forced 10 year liquidation of assets like with an IRA when inherited. Again, I value my flexibility over all else, and the ability to use funds when I dictate, not wait until Im 5912 if I dont want to, or be forced into some other situation that may not be preferential for what my goals are. My end game is to have a brokerage account that generates a sufficient amount of income annually that supports my life so I have the option to work or not, and allows me to do the things that I want to do. Maybe I want to travel and volunteer at national parks and just hike all day real possibility that I may do, pack up and possibly move part of the year when my kid is older and decides to attend college somewhere buy a rental and make money with this likely, add to the rentals that I already have as well, do some side gig work to stay busy, or whatever it may be. But if im 50 and this takes place, know what kind of investment makes this more difficult to achieve? pretax retirement accounts. I can turn off reinvestment in a brokerage whenever I want and just take some cash instead, I cant do that with an IRA. So does this cost me some current dollars? Sure, but most of that is at a preferred rate anyways, and I dont live the lifestyle I could if I just spent all I have, so I can make it work. Im playing the long game and know what my end goal is, and when the day arrives that my kid decides to go to college, and Im ready to just pack up and sell the place I have and travel, or be closer to him, or whatever it may be, I have the option to make that decision without fear of tax consequence based on where my income is coming from, and when a lot of that is preferred rates, and I am pretty minimal income otherwise because of it, a lot of it can carry a 0 preferred rate in todays world. No guarantee that lasts, but to an extent I look at it as me prepaying my retirement plans on dividends and gains for living how I want and on my terms later.

replies.text: It sounds like you have a fortunate family from a financial standpoint that have all made good long lasting financial relationships and have had success with working with financial advisors to manage their money while they have spent time in the business or work earning enough to have extra to invest. That is a powerful combination they have accomplished. It appears your parents and grandparents have consolidated on a set of accomplished advisors. I would move your money to that set of advisors so it will be together with their future gifts. Frankly as much as you like your financial advisor and how helpful he has been to you, you are not a drop in the bucket in his gross income, so he is losing little financially by you moving away. I suspect you are a likeable guy and he is doing it as much as a friend as anything so will be sad to see you go, but will wish you Godspeed and success as you leave. I spent most of my career in a major broker dealer working in a regional capacity and helping our top teams manage their UHNW clients and their families. It is a fortunate thing to be exposed to the level of help you will get from a large accomplished team of HNW advisors. Enjoy the relationship as it builds.

For 3, if youre willing to put some time in, i would suggest finding an hourly financial advisor when you need consultation then using a financial planning tool like Projection Lab to manage your own financial plan. Thats what my fiance and I do. Projection lab is good for modeling different scenarios and it provides nice graphs using your assetsdebtsincomelife events etc. theres a free sandbox mode if you just want to play around w it

In all honesty all are trying to share your wealth. Some have more people skills than others. I often play one CFP against a llc to keep both on their toes. In your case I believe you should have an small account under family plan. From there you do what you feel like that fits your model. Earlier I dealt direct with each company reinvestment department because of high brokerage fees. Later I consolidated into different accounts in a same brokerage that I can walk in drop off signed documents, deposit and talk to them about tax saving plans. Over the years I had many advisors, stock trader Ivy league graduate and had lunch with branch managers and they asked me if I want to apply for ipo stocks and programs not available to many. Most only do as requested with minimal interaction. The one you had for so many years probably never earned much from you but he is a good source for go to questions. I really do not encourage you putting all your savings with same guy family member works with. Best is avoid giving out too much personal question.

I would avoid using ANY family friend as a financial advisor. Dont mix business with personal relationships. Because when you want to end the relationship, its awkward as you are finding out. I also dont see any benefit to using multiple advisors. If you use an advisor, they need to know the whole picture to make recommendations, not just the part invested with them. To break up, you make it short and sweet Weve decided were going to manage our investments ourselves going forward. We appreciate your help and guidance that got us this far and were ready to take over from here. Then you move the investments to your own account wherever you set it up, such as Fideltity, Schwab, etc. by telling the NEW custodian to move the assets from the old one. When your old advisor sees another company requesting the transfer, they will have already heard from you whats happening. Personally I dont believe there is any magic involved in investing. I personallly follow the Bogleheads philosophy so I dont use an advisor, and that system has done great for me. Easy too.

The value of an advisor is to motivate you to do more and organize and automate you. Your long time sounds like he was just getting started, and he is not pushing you hence not worth it. You should put the names of the firms and what the management fees are, and list the biggest mutual funds just the symbol so you can learn how to look up internals. And there is no etiquette for brokerage, if someone is not providing value, you pull the account to someone who will. Most advisors are mediocre just like most employees in any profession. This is a money game, the is the score, biggest number at the end wins...

When I first started working, I always thought I need a FA for investments and I had even asked my colleagues. I was so naive that I kept all my money in savings account paying almost nothing. I moved from another country so I didnt have any clue on IRA and my employer didnt offer 401k. I researched on my own and eventually opened IRA but still was naive enough to not contribute every year. Eventually, I became more intelligent. Just before Covid hit, I was looking at investing 100k that I had been saving. I thought its a big amount, I need a FA to help me invest properly. I met few but wasnt sold on any. So, I decided to do it on my own and I am glad the portfolio has been doing good. Over the last 4 years it has been at least matching SP. We now have a brokerage account, HSA, 2 Roth IRAs and 2 401ks. All retirement accounts have 3 funds FSELX, FXAIX, and VTI in 106030 allocation. I have also learned to feel, one needs a FA after 5m assets or if getting a 1m inheritance. Not only is that a life changing amount but one also needs to do proper tax planning. In your case, I think it is safe to assume, between your parents, your wifes parents and your grandparents, you two are likely to get significant inheritance combined mid 6 figures or may be even more. Hence, having a relationship with a FA would be beneficial. Id speak with both your grandparents and inlaws FA. Understand their plan, their investment philosophy, fees etc, do some research of my own and then pick one.
