replies.text: HSA has an advantage that no other accounts have, which is no FICA taxes on the contributions. Thats an immediate 7.65 gain

Im not an expert, but I researched this quite a bit a few years ago to begin utilizing the benefits of an HSA account. Heres some info... Assuming you have 26 pay periods per year, your low deductible plan will cost you 10,400 in premiums and wont begin providing benefits until at least an additional 650 is spent on medical costs for a total of 11,050. The high deductible plan will cost 6,500 in premiums and wont provide benefits until you pay at least 3,500 of medical expenses for a total of 11,000. Of course, this is assuming the deductible for only you. If you someone else in your family is the main source of medical bills, then youd have to rerun the numbers and it would vary some. Typically youre predicting one of two things. Either you predict that you wont spend much on medical expenses, in which case you actually save money going with the high deductible plan or you anticipate getting close to meeting your out of pocket max, in which case it seems your low deductible plan would be the most cost effective. The worst case scenario is paying a total of 12,400 for the year with the low deductible plan and 14,500 with the high deductible plan. The best case scenario is paying 10,400 for the low deductible plan and 6,500 for the high deductible plan. Some people like playing it safe and spreading the cost over time, so they go with the low deductible plan, but other people are willing to take the chance to potentially save a few thousand dollars if there arent many medical needs throughout the year and take the cheaper high deductible plan. Thats up to you and your familys situation or what makes you the most comfortable. The benefit of an HSA is that it has triple tax benefits, so it isnt taxed when you contribute, gains arent taxed, and it isnt taxed when you use it. You wont find that with an IRA or 401k. From what Ive seen, a lot of people use this as an additional retirement account as it has the best tax benefits of any account offered. They contribute the max amount allowed per year, invest it, and dont use it for reimbursement until retirement. I also believe that if you dont use the funds by a certain age I think either 67 or 72, it can start being used for ordinary expenses, but I cant remember the details on that. Obviously, laws can change around these things also. You do not have to use the HSA funds immediately and instead can pay medical expenses with a regular form of payment. If you do this and keep the medical receipt, you can choose, at any point in the future, to get reimbursement from your HSA. For example, you have a medical bill for 3,000 in 2025 and pay with your debit card. Save the receipt and keep any HSA funds invested and growing. In 2035 maybe you are looking to make a large purchase. You could, in 2035, use that receipt from 2025 and get reimbursed the 3,000 from your HSA. The benefit of this is that you have been able to grow that money for an additional 10 years tax free. The main point with HSAs is that they are the best tax opportunity account offered. I dont recall all of the aspects of it, but listed the main ones that resonated with me. Hopefully that is useful!

I started with an HSA for two years. But I have a family of seven and it seemed like it was costing me more because of the higher detectable I was paying out of pocket. If I had a smaller family with few health issues I would absolutely still have an HSA. For now the PPO works best us

If you can afford an HSA without it affecting your 401k contribution, why not? Its still pretax in and no tax out as long as you are paying medical expenses. It will accrue just like a 401k. Unless you have a major medical issue, I dont see why you wouldnt?
If you work until youre 65, you have 22 years left. In 22 years, you can build a nice sized HSA because like everyone else, youre going to have medical expenses when you retire.
Hell, Im thinking of starting one and Im in my 50s.

Husband and I started an HSA about 10 years ago in our early to mid 40s. We are relatively healthy but do use our HSA for medical expenses. Even with regular use and a couple of higher medical expense years, we have combined a little more than what we contributed in our separate HSA accounts. Weve been fortunate that it was a good 10 years of returns, and it has worked out well for us. We are now in our early to mid 50s and plan to continue using our HSA the same way until it no longer makes sense to do so.

Damn no commenters actually read your question.... Personally I opt for a high deductible plan as me and my family are pretty young and healthy. The company contribution to HSA and the savings on lower premium with the high deductible plan more than cover any routine health expenses we have. And if something unforeseen happens... Im only 8k in the hole for severe medical event.

Our health coverage never included eyeglasses or dental, so HSA was our choice, as we could spend from there. We had lower medical costs than either eyes or teeth, so HDHP was perfect. I never see anyone but me mention that some States offer a health savings account which doesnt depend on your coverage type or income. We can put up to 4,500 in each account and it saves us our 6.75 tax rate.
Be careful. I went up until 40 with very few doctors visits. Since turning 40 currently 44, its one thing after another.

I started with an HSA a few years ago. Then all the kids needed braces. I paid cash for the braces, and left the HSA alone. Its growing interest free. I can take it, but, if I took it, and put future money in a normal brokerage then Id have to pay taxes on the gains. So it is 2nd to last on the list of funds to raid. If you dont use the HSA, when you turn 65 you can withdraw it without needing a doctors note, but you have to pay income tax on it. Ill pay myself back for my braces bill when Im 64. Take it out without having to pay the income tax. Most healthcare is used by people over 50. Looking at this long term, theres a good chance you or your wife will start to hit those deductibles or just have some expenses and you can pull that money out without having to pay the income taxes. Less insurance is better than more insurance. An extra 3900 that you have a choice of how to spend or save is better than guaranteeing you have to spend that 3900 whether you benefit from it or not. Risk is you have to spend 1100 more but, that is only if two of you get sick to the tune of several thousand dollars. Insurance prices their premiums to make the higher deductibles plans the ones to have. They are trying to shift the costs to consumers. This trend means that having the HSA in your back pocket leaves you covered, or sets you up to save more on insurance down the road. The 1000 contribution from the employer is an extra bonus. They are trying to incentivize you to take the cheaper plan. The more expensive plan is likely more than 1000 more expensive for them. You can max that HSA at about 8000, and youd be well to put at least the 3900 premium savings in it, but you should consider maxing it if you can.

HSA and investments aside, the more expensive plan has you spending 3900 for the slight chance youll save 1100 overall for the year, if you hit those maxes. good health means the chances the cheaper plan comes in cheaper is good. From the 6000 difference in maxes, subtract the 3900 difference in premium and the 1000 from the employer for the HSA. That means only if you spend more than 6900 in health care, will the lower deductible plan come up cheaper, and even then it has to be in a particular way with 2 people spending 3500. If just one of you gets sick, the cheaper plan is still cheaper. If just one of you gets sick for more than 3500, then youre still 400 ahead in premiums even after paying that deductible, and you have the 1000 from the employer.

We have had HSA accounts at various times and did not particularly enjoy them. We have three young children, and even when my partner was pregnant, the upfront costs we had to absorb before the plan kicked created quite a bit of problems in terms of cash flows and just managing our monthly expenses. If you dont have young children, preexisting health conditions, or a decent amount of money in reserves, HSA is probably going to hurt you more than help. Quick example... my asthma medication cost 300 each month out of pocket if I used an HSA. But through my insurance, it costs me 6 dollars. So, as long as I refill my asthma medicine 4 times in a year, the value of the reduced premiums from the HSA versus insurance basically zeroes out. Additionally, the advantages of the HSA are more or less realized if you can contribute the premium differences and allocate to the HSA. In other words, youre not necessarily saving money. Youre just taking on more the risk yourself. For most people with families on a tight budget, I would argue that HSA is way too risky.

I would second taking a HSA. You will be surprised to know that HSA can be used on so many general items like the below and using a HSA on these will reduce your taxable expenses further. Bandaids, gauze etc Suncare products with SPF15 Sunscreens, Suncare moisturizers, Lipbalms with SPF etc AspirinTylenol, Vicks Nasal sprays, Nasal cleaning sinus cleaning products Like Neilmed etc Feminine hygiene products like tampons, pads Acne creams and Acne care products. Biofreeze Percussion massagers Sanitizers, masks, PPE etc Reading glasses, eye cleaners Prescription glasses, lens etc Tums Condoms Baby wipes Pregnancy related accessories and breast pump etc. Heating pads for cramps etc

Provided that youre healthy and have no major medical expenses its absolutely the way to go. I personally pay out of pocket for everything and use it as a retirement account. Also if for some reason expenses start to get out of control or something like cancer etc pop up, then you wait until the next enrollment period and switch back to the better insurance. Typically if you put the maximum deduction in youll have enough to cover the higher deductible after a year. Everything on top of that is just a bonus.
HSA has the most tax advantages of any account type in the USA. Up to you if thats worth it for your situation.
You can always change it later. One year of max out of pocket likely shouldnt hurt you much even on an HDHP. Personally, Id roll the dice.

Devils advocate, 43 is an age where the body decides to take a turn its actually been studied. Hopefully you and your family stay healthy but all it takes is a few things and the HSA idea will go out the window.

The HDHP plan seems pretty good. Consider signing up and maximizing your HSA contributions. Set aside money for up to the OOP Maximum or deductible, since your individual bills will be more, but youll get probably save more from the lower premiums and HSA tax benefits. Some notes Another comment mentions a FICA tax exemption. This only applies if contribution are made directly from your paycheck or employer. If you make about 200K a year. So, you probably exceed the Social security limit, but are probably under the Medicare surtax limit. So the extra tax savings from FICA would likely be 1.45, and not 7.65. If you have two W2 employers in a year, both will deduct at 7.65 initially, but youll get the excess Social Security back on your tax return. The right health plan for you depends on the options available. If the PPO and HDHP have different networks, that could be an important difference. Also make sure that you arent discouraged from getting necessary care if you are on the HDHP. You may see higher bills than you are used to, but based on the specific plans you mentioned, you are likely saving money. Here, the PPO probably costs between 11700 and 13700, and HDHP costs between 5500 and 13500, if you count the HSA employer contribution. Theres other factors, since its harder to estimate costs on PPO, so youre more likely to be able to use pretax HSA funds to pay for care on the HDHP. This also assumes you only use innetwork care. Assuming the networks are the same, its probably going to be tough to find a scenario where the PPO costs less than the HDHP. If you get the HSA employer contribution for a partial year enrollment, its probably even better to sign up this year. However, one disadvantage of the HDHP is that you might owe a lot more earlier in the year due to the deductible, even though the cost savings are spread throughout the year. So PPO might sometimes be better for a partial year since the additional premium isnt as much. With a HDHP, you can use the last month rule to make HSA contributions as if you were enrolled the full year if you were enrolled on December 1. You just need to make sure you have a HDHP for the entire subsequent year. If you cant maximize it from your paycheck, you can make an HSA contribution until the April tax deadline for the prior year. HSA accounts are portable. If you want, you can open a HSA at another custodian and transfer your money and sometimes investments to them. This can be useful since there are HSA custodians with low or no fees. You also can use it for any future healthvisiondental costs, even if you switch to a plan that doesnt allow contributions like PPO or Medicare in the future. CA and NJ dont treat HSAs as taxdeferred. If you are a taxresident there, you dont get a state taxdeduction.
Plus its not taxed by the state so its more than that even.

This was immensley helpful and should be stickied! I was doing the rough math in my head, but this was laid out well, thank you! One note for others, I purposely did PPO because Im in a lot of high risk sports like biking, hockey, snowboarding, etc. Im usually good for one ER or Urgent Care visit a year though hopefully nothing serious so being able to not worry about the costs of service, stitches, xrays, MRIs, etc. Has been nice but I may rethink this strategy...
Very useful. Ty

To add to this The IRS only cares about the amount contributed to all HSAs combined. This means that if you take the HDHP, you can open a separate HSA at any custodian you like available at most brokerage firms, I have one through Fidelity. Just keep your yearly combined contributions meaning the 1000 from work, and whatever personal contributions you make under the annual limit which is currently 4150 for an individual and 8300 for a family plan in 2024. You will be able to get that sweet triple tax benefit with a lot more money. At least at Fidelity, there are no custodial fees or expenses other than the usual expense ratio of MFs and ETFs, and they will let you invest any amount into a broad range of securities. One other thing to consider is that when you get to Medicare age, you will have plenty of expenses! I was talking to a friend at work about the wonders of HSAs and he said I thought Medicare was free! Ha! There are plenty of deductibles, monthly premiums, copays, prescription costs... and all of them are eligible to be paid taxfree from your HSA. Even if you dont use all your HSA money, after 65 it becomes just like another traditional IRA if you dont use the money for healtcare. Just make withdrawals and pay regular income tax on it. Personally, every year I have a work contribution to my regular HSA account, which I use for usual medical expenses. I also contribute the rest up to the limit into my retirement HSA that I have fully invested in ETFs and will just stay there, growing until Im on Medicare.
Thats fantastic to hear. Congrats
This is what scares me.

I have a 2year old. And me, him, and my wife are all relatively healthy, with no huge out of pocket costs, minus one small prescription my wife gets monthly. Which isnt TOO insane. I think it would be 150 a month before our deductible is met. Right now its 5

I think this is an end thread type response. I went through these same calculations, and started HSA around 45 or so. I figured if I didnt use it for 2 years, I would already have enough in it to start paying for any expenses that might come up in the future. And as long as the expenses were below the annual HSA contribution, I would be adding to my corpus. Essentially, I was in analysisparalysis phase for a few years, really should have started HSA the first time I thought about it. It is a nobrainer.
Same, I think its also important to weigh their lifestyle when factoring these things.
Should be fine.

replies.text: Have you considered REITs first? Owning property is often tax inefficient and can be a real headache if you are not up for the job of being a landlord

Talk to your business banker and see what they have to say. Im a commercial loan underwriter and my bank, along with just about all of them in my area, started getting a lot more restrictive on lending for rentals a couple of years ago. Obviously every bank is going to be different and it will be market dependent. Anyway, youll probably need to bring at least 25 for a down payment. Likely more if the apartments are consider 14 family which is what it sounds like. The bank will want deposits too. Deposits were a point of emphasis for just about every bank the last 2 years. My bank wont lend for a rental without at least 10 of the loan amount on deposit, for example.

REITS and owning private real estate are very different. REITS have shown to be tremendously sensitive to movements in interest rates. Private real estate is certainly impacted by changing rates but the volatility is much softer. Plus if OP is cash flowing their rentals and had locked in a rate on their loans, they arent going to see that impact where as a REIT basically marks to market every day. Even with a little dividend income from a REIT, I dont think I would put them in the same category.

Why do you use a management company when you are general contractor ? I assume you are licensed and your business is an actual working entity that has back office capabilities for paperwork and labor for actual maintenance.

this! of course its personal preference, but for me being a landlord is the last thing i want. id gladly take a lower return knowing i dont have to deal with that. and unless the location is amazing, owning real estate doesnt even return that much better than your average reit portfolio.
I think there needs to be a real want to be a landlord. Reits can get you exposure to diversified real estate, and offer more protection through the diversification.
for sure. and i dont dismiss the idea of owning physical property like real estate or land. it all has its place. but its just not for me.

replies.text: historical data has shown that dividend paying stocks tended to outperform their non dividend paying counterparts. If dividends dont inherently add value, why is this the case? Life is not just about numbers. And the differences between dividend payments and stock buybacks involve a great deal more than math. Dividends are usually distributed in a systematic way, and cutting dividend payments is seen as a very bad sign. So, a dividend is in effect a statement by management that they believe the company can perform and continue to deliver into the future. Boeing is a case study. Prior to 1998 investment in new aircraft programs and the companys reputation was seen as a way to protect investors, and the dividend, well into the future. Post 1998 the Jack Welch school that came to control the company was focused on short term results and stock buybacks. The difference between Boeing today and what is called in the industry legacy Boeing is stark.

This is well documented but too often ignores the behavioral story. You touch on the misconceptions in your final paragraph. But perhaps they know themselves. By that I mean there are people for whom dividends have psychological benefits, meaning the ability to hold equity at all is improved by knowing the dividends are coming in.
In certain countries like Australia dividends have special treatment from a tax perspective also, which makes it an attractive component of total return.

What about people who are in distribution. Doesnt having some focus not total focus on quality stocks that are divided players help with cash flow during periods where sequence of return risk would be detrimental

Its a nice thought experiment, but youre taking it too far in your conclusions. Assumptions like management will always spend money in good faith to maximize earnings are useful if you want to make a world that is spreadsheetcompatible, but massively off the mark from the real world. In the real world management has incentives like getting the stock price to a certain number by a certain time to get a payout, future be damned. Creating unrealistic narratives about future earning to justify or increase PE ratios you know are excessive. Tech is a huge part of the SP500 and these problems are very common in tech. Around the dotcom crash this all got so bad that nobody could give out any dividends at all, for fear of demonstrating that they dont have endless golden geese lined up that the money would be better spent on. These days theyve gotten a little better about this and your Apple, Microsoft, and Google at least pay out a nominal dividend of like 0.51. Investors regularly get their money pissed up the wall like this in tech, when they would have been much better off just receiving it as a dividend than having tens of billions wasted on the metaverse with promises that all life would revolve around this concept in a few years, only to have them say actually never mind its all fake after a few years of stock options vesting at high valuations. Of course, were in the middle of a similar bubble with AI, so this all seems quaint now, but trust me, in a few years there will be a lot of people saying I wish they had just given me the money. So yeah, I like a small dividend, just to maintain a culture that this is my money they are playing with, and if they dont have a good use for it then Ill take it. A lot of this applies to share buybacks as well, although theyre prone to more bad incentives as they work through share price, so management is incentivized to do them even when the stock is already overvalued, and the personal incentives mentioned above etc.
Are dividend payouts on average less volatile than stock prices?

What you said is true. However dividend stocks typically fit in the Value category and they do have substantially different characteristics than growth stocks. Generally larger older companies with less volatility and more predictable cash flows or they wouldnt be paying dividends. So if you are trying to make the point that only younger faster growing growth stocks are the only thing you should invest in I would call you Wrong.

Part of the reason for dividends is they discipline management through requiring payouts and ensures they dont squander the companies cash. This is covered more in finance classes under treasury operations than capital structure. However, I think its a valid reason for dividends. True you may not want a fast growing company to pay dividends and instead invest in growth. However, most companies dont fall into that category and would likely waste extremely large investments. I guess you could make an argument for stock buybacks since they are more tax efficient but because they are expected at regular intervals they dont quite have the same ability to discipline management.

However, dividends themselves are an irrelevant criterion for investment selection. thats not what Modigliani and Miller claimed. Their research has been consistently distorted and misrepresented over the years. Note that MM didnt say that dividends were irrelevant they said, under their extremely narrow conditions, that dividend payout ratios should be irrelevant to the overall value of the firm. That is a specific finance claim, not a generalized disregard for dividend payments. It is not what MM said its what people now think they said. Theres a big difference. Daniel Peris, The Ownership Dividend Routledge, 2024
The payout of dividends is derisking. You could ride a growth stock all the way up and then all the way down with nothing to show for it.

I mean I appreciate the analysis but were splitting hairs when looking at the two most popular ETF, VOO any SP variant and SCHD. VOO 10 year fidelity stats 13.34 with 1.29 dividend SCHD 10 year fidelity stats 11.71 with 3.29 dividend The difference in total average return is 1.52, which is roughly the same difference between their dividend payout. The whole growthtotal returndividend drama is unnecessary and really only applies to high yield or yield max dividend products.

Empirical evidence, such as the drop in stock prices on the exdividend date, supports this theory. When a dividend is paid, the share price tends to decrease by the amount of the dividend, as cash leaving the company is reflected by a reduction in book value per share. Thats not just just a market tendency, its whats required to happen. All opening bids and offers are adjusted down by the amount of the dividend and any shareholders at the open are entitled to the dividend.

The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. So if this is false and dividends are better, dividends win. If this is true and dividends are the same....dividends also win because its the same thing. So whats the point of this discussion? In reality, these kind of theories dont mean shit in the real world because of many reasons, one of many being that many times a company cant reinvest capital with the same efficiency as their previous investments. Anyways, my portfolio has an average dividend of around 4.2

Yeah, this gets parroted a lot, esp on these forums, but a number of the issues I find to be untrue, misleading, or very halfassed or halfbaked. There is no reason 1 dividends is better than 1 capital appreciation. Except, you know. If you want a dollar. Theyre saying well, you can just do things to get the dollar. Which assumes those things are instant, effortless, and guaranteed like a dividend. A dollar is not like capital appreciation of a dollar just like 50,000 isnt like your house being worth 50k more. Oh, just sell your house. Or sell 50k of your houseTwo bathrooms. Its all the same! No, A and A are the same. 8.17 and 8.17 are the same. But if you say things are exactly equivalent, they better be. Because there are all sorts of equations you can plug into if AB and they dont work here. Congrats on reposting one of the forums go to mantras which they repeat with religious fervor.

By the same logic buying a House and renting it out is just as useless as Dividend paying Stocks. The Theory misses the Point that you want to achieve a passive cashflow and that one may value a passive reliable cashflow over 23 higher total return. You have to price in the Fexebility of Dividends. You are giving yourself a raise with dividend where with Accumulating ETFs and Stocks you only want to sell if you need the Money. With Dividend i may use the Money i gain to pay for a nice Diner, or Holidays, this is something you dont want to do with Accumulation ETFs Dividends are more for people wanting to enjoy their Money always and not just when they are Old. And if i dont need my Dividend Money it gets reinvested.

Thank you for an insightful post! You would not believe how many people are in love with dividends and dont realize the consequences of them and the irrelevance of them on performance. I think people get really confused because many of them think that they cant get compounding growth without dividends or distribution.
The application of the theory only works if you intend to buy the firm otherwise it is meaningless.
There must be enough of other cash income than salary. This is priority 1. As fast as possible. Can be achieved with rental property or bonds or why not with dividends.
This is an amazing post. VERY thoughtful and considerate of all sides and why each might be wrong or right. Thank you wise one. This must have taken a lot of time and energy to write. 3

When you study for the series 65 or any other securities licenses one of the first things they teach you is that its illegal to sell a stock on the premise of an upcoming dividend....even the regulators know markets work efficiently and those dividends are already priced in. Dividends are nothing more than money that isnt being reinvested into the company. If anything Id rather not have them in favor of the company withholding those funds to grow more.

The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. Under this theory, a companys value is determined solely by its earnings power and investment decisions, not by how it distributes its profits. Whether profits are retained or distributed, the firms underlying valuation remains the same. I highlighted the key phrase in that paragraph you wrote. That lines says taxes, law changes, wares, natural disasters, and diseases, and criminal activity are Irrelevant. Clearly that is not the case if you look through history. The resent a pandemic and hurricanes and Russias invasion of Ukraine have all had massive impacts on society and many businesses did not survive. Looking further back Enron was seen as a great investment until it was people discovered that the executives lied about the companies performance and illegally manipulated energy prices in california. A tariff war was initiated by US government in 1929 resulted in in an about 60 drop in trade and the SP500 loosing 13 of it value in about 2 days. Add in WW2 and the economy needed 14 years to recover. That one assumption in the theory make it it invalid. Things beyond the control of the company can quickly turn it from profitable to a money looser and eventually kill the company. Look at the dividend return and capital gains earnings of the SP500 seperately 74 of of the funds performance comes from reinvesting the dividends Only 26 came from capital gains. Clearly the dividends from the index, as small as it is, are important. Clearly the divided irrelevance theory is not a valid theory. this video also explains the problems with the theory.

Everything you say is true but investing is a personal situation driven game. During your accumulation phase you would be wrong to have any allocation other than a diversified portfolio that is spread between growth and value with some adjustment for whether we are in a Value or a Growth phase in the market. In the Early Accumulation phase you should be heavily invested in equities as you dont much care about down cycles as you have little money at risk. In the late accumulation phase you start to build in a strategy for up and down markets as you now have some principal to protect. In the Preretirement stage you start to worry more about beta and less about alpha particularly if you have done a good job of accumulation. In Retirement your goals are preservation and income, so less beta is more important than excess alpha unless you are late to the party. Assuming you have hit your goals, then joining rdividend and forgetting a growth allocation makes total sense. In that stage assuming a good number, you can use the dividends and leave the kids the equities at whatever value they may have when you are gone. People throw around a 45 wdl number which is doable with a dividend stream and no stock sales if you pick your stocks correctly.
Is this Ben Felixs Twin?
There is no reason why 1 in the form of a dividend should be preferred more than 1 in the form of capital appreciation. This is not true as the distribution can be taxed differently.
No amount of evidence will convince dividend investors. Its a religion.

Bro, what are you talking about? When it comes to investing, the only thing that matters is how I get money into my pocket. Dividends are just one of many options I can use to get money into my pocket. Theres a time and a place for every tool in the toolbox. Also, Im skeptical of anything from 1961 discussing dividends because 1 interest rates were much higher and 2 buybacks didnt exist. Buybacks and dividends often go together since they are often a sign of a mature business.

I would rather have a ,,value company buy back stocks than pay dividends.

Stock price does not drop by the dividend paid. Thats absolutely false. Ive often witnessed rising stock prices on dividend payment date and at other times seen it fall by much more than the dividend payment. Also, dividends are not taxed as capital gains which makes them more valuable in view of the taxes. Lastly, youre quoting textbook theory. There is no such thing as a frictionless market in real life and while theories are nice, reality is much messier and does not adhere very closely to most of these textbook theories. This is why your professor could always explain it in retrospect but your professor wasnt Warren Buffet or even close. That said, I invest in both dividend paying stocks and nondividend stocks. Decision to invest in a company is multi factorial and so is how you wish to take your profits.

Dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. Its all in here isnt it, if only dividend haters would understand what this means, itd give a rest to all the rest of the claptrap arguments they use.
Share dilution is something to pay attention to. For example Realty Income pays a stable 5 dividend per year. However, they have added 21.37 new shares this year. That means your actual return is 15.

Id actually argue that all else equal, dividends are actually a structural headwind to returns. As you point out, dividends are just a mandatory liquidation of a portion of the market cap of the company. Any investor who owns the stock via a basket e.g. an index fund investor who reinvests dividends is effectively going short the stock vs long the other stocks in the basket and actually reinvesting an even smaller portion than they would have otherwise because the dividend reduces the companys weight in the index. Extending the work of Koijen et al, this imbalanced flow should have a lasting price impact on the stock relative to the other constituents in excess of the fundamental change in the value of the companys assets

You would be knowledgable on a subject then, perhaps you can answer it. My understanding is, your actual numerical value of debt is essentially irrelevant provided you have the cashflow to make a lender comfortable. Is this ballpark accurate?

Correct. The most common way a lender will look at the quantum of debt they are willing to extend is a multiple on cash flow. So if you generate 100m in cash flow a year, a lender will most likely be willing to extend 300 400m or 3 to 4x cash flow. The primary reason being is a company will trade at some much higher multiple say 7 to 20 times depending on business so if youre only lent 3 to 4, you are safely inside a potential EV of the company. Secondarily, the lender wants to ensure you generate enough cash flow to cover the interest expense of the debt. There are other underwriting metholdogies though, multiple on recurring revenue or pure asset based lending against liquidation value of assets are two other common ones

replies.text: Not a fan of the expression since it basically implies that every public firm with multiple product lines is like an ETF. But I get it and it makes sense. PG is good they just trade at a high valuation due to their predictability and sustainable growth. So when you buy them with those same expectations, you arent getting very far.

Funnily enough about 25 years ago I had a similar thought about Philip Morris before numerous splits into more focused entities like PMI, Altria, Kraft, etc.. The company made everything from cigs to chips to beer how could it fail? Well, it didnt fail but it also didnt grow enthusiastically compared to say Big Tech and by proxy a broader ETF that had tech exposure. Even when the economy tanks these more defensive consumable stocks in mature segments dont rocket up with the same enthusiasm as tech has in a relatively new segment. So you may limit downside volatility as people will continue to buy PG products no matter what but you miss out on the upside by putting all your money there. I inherited a small IRA with PG about five years ago, watched it for several years, and nuked it this year for standard broad ETFs and Im not looking back. I get the idea, though.
Look into the Tyco International scandal and you will understand why conglomerates diversification. Youre not wrong that PG often holds up countercyclically, just dont mistake it for an ETF.

Im not sure any stock is crisis proof. some hold up better than others, and consumer staples tend to be very slow but steady good longterm performers. but there are different types of crisis events that might cause different problems in various industries Dave Ramsey has talked about helping a woman who worked for PG and her entire portfolio was PG stock IIRC. then there was some problem at the company and the stock crashed by 50, when the overall market was down only like 10 that year also IIRC. Hi I am in similar situation as you. I am also saving a deposit for buying a home in Australia in next 35 years as well. How I view my situation is I would like to own asset stock, bond or real estate in the long run. Since I am not in the financial position to buying a house. But I can invest in a portfolio of stock and saving or bond to enjoy compund interests. My split is 8020, where 80 is in the form of stock index ETFs. I belive this related to our question regarding savinginvesting percentage. As many others has mentioned, it does depends on your risk tolerance level. I am sharing my as a refers for you. The common belief for asset allocation is percentage for allocating save asset should be roughly your age. For example, if you are at your 20s, you should invest 80 into say stock index, and 20 remaind in saving or bond where is it much less risky. So you might want to adjust this percentage to match your risk tolerance level. Back to my case, my hope is that my stockbond portfolio will increase in the relatively long run i.e. 35 years. I saw some stats that in Australia the average annual return of real estate and stock over past 30 years are similar. Based on this assumption which again is just a blief of mine. It makes sense to me to invest in my stockbond portfolio for the next 35 years. Depends on the situation in 35 years time, I will then decide what percentage of my portfolio that I am willing to sell for buying my home. Above is just my humble opinion and what I am practicing. By no means these are sophisticated. Hope this help to address your question. Like you, I would hear and learn from other investers who are likely to be much more experienced then me Happy saving and investing!

As others have said, how much risk are you willing to take on? If youre okay with your investments barely growing, or potentially ending up negative highly unlikely if you go in on a solid SP500 fundETF for a 35 year horizon then I would park a majority think like 60 of it in something like FXAIX and hold it long enough to qualify for capital gains tax min 1 year. Whatever you dont want to put into a large fund, put it in a money market fund or purchase 36 month CDs. If you are not risk tolerant and you feel more comfortable having the cash available for safety and are worried the US could enter a recession, then youd want to have most of money in the HYSA or a money market fund. If you feel like you may need to access that money, youd stay away from CDs. If you dont need access to it, but also arent comfortable letting it ride in the stock market, then CDs are a popular route. The key thing is you want to diversify. Dont put all your eggs in one basket. Even if you are risk averse, you likely can still afford to put a percentage into large market and CDs if you have a solid 36 months of emergency cash saved up.

As others have stated, it all depends on your risk tolerance. Right NOW, with HYSAs still offerring 5, ive got half of my savings in HYSA. Im 51 though. If i was 30, Id probably only have only 20 in HYSA and the rest in the market. Once HYSA interest gets back down to 13, if i was younger, Id increase my stocks age to 80. At my age though, Ill probably just go to 65 max in the market, and mostly increase my bonds and TBill holdings, because I want safer investmenets with less risk. Unless theres a 25 pull back in the markets, at which point ill probably put most of my HYSA money back into the market for 5 years or so before tansitioning back out to safer investments with lower returns.

I dont think a fixed percentage is a good way to approach this. You would be better off prioritizing what you want to do and front loading it. A savings account is a much worse investment than either a house or a good index fund over the longer term. Either save up aggressively and get into the housing market, or if you arent ready for that in your life situation then front load your stock investments so they have more time to grow.

Inflation is reported year over year so when you see 3 inflation reported that means the particular basket of goods used to measure inflation has increased 3 in the last 12 months. According to a random calculator I found on smartasset.com the cumulative inflation rate over the last 5 years has been 22.7.
Inflation being 2.5 today tells you prices rose 2.5 over the last 12 months. It tells you nothing about what happened the previous 4 years.

Thats not how inflationor disinflation, in this case works. The high inflation rates we saw during and after the pandemic are now baked in to the prices of goods and services, and no amount of disinflationa reduction of the inflation rate, not a reversal of inflation will bring back preCOVID prices. What has happened is that the rate at which goods and services naturally increase in price over time has been brought back to a more reasonable level. This is a good thing, and means that prices should be at a more steady level compared to before. If prices were to return to preCOVID levels, we would be dealing with deflation. Longstoryshort, the implications that deflation has on the broader economy means that deflation is not a good thing. In fact, a return to preCOVID pricesdeflation would actually be a sign of exactly what youre speculating, a weakening economy. That said, there has also been a rise of corporate greed and price gouging, which has artificially raised the price of certain goods and services. This is separate from inflation, and absolutely needs to be addressed by our government. ELI5 Inflation is natural. Most of the time, prices go up slowly. During extreme eventsCOVID, the amount of inflation can go up. Afterwards, the government can then do things to make the amount of inflation go back down to normal levels. When this happens, the prices dont go back down, but instead are back at to the point where they go up slowly. Im not an expert.
Seems like your first step should be looking up the definition of inflation.
I think the squeeze you feel is from the additional corporate greed on top of the natural inflation. Plus some industries are just naturally gonna be betterworse than others at various times.

replies.text: If thats the house you like, then buy it. The 1st question then becomes, whether or not to sell your current house now or in the spring? For a spring time sale, work out how much it will cost you to carry that vacant building vs how much you stand to gain by waiting for the better market time. If the gain will be more than the cost, then wait untill spring to sell it, otherwise, sell it now. If it makes sense for the spring time sale, then 2nd question is, how to come up with the money for new house? You could either sell some of your investments or finance the new or current property with a HELOC or Mortgage. Do your investments generally make a higher percent return than the current interest rate percent would be for financing? If yes, then finance, if no, then sell off some investments.

I just spent the last year as the executor of my mothers estate. I was finally able to sell her home and close a couple of weeks ago. Owning one house is rough enough. Owning two is a nightmare. We only lived three miles apart. But having two sets of bills to pay, power, water, gas, lawn, weed spray, and her pool makes it an absolute money pit. No way will I ever own two homes again. I would rather live in a van down by the river.

Currently I have my emergency fund in the TBIL etf which is for short term treasury bills so it pays about 5 dividends a year currently. Its more liquid than an actual 3 month treasury bill because you can sell it anytime the market is open. The price of the etf fluctuates a tiny bit but not much. Its probably the safest way to protect your emergency fund from inflation but also if the market crashes and you need it then half of it wont be lost. During market crashes and recessions lots of people lose their jobs. The dividends from my TBIL etf get invested into Vanguard funds. Its about 120 or 130 every month. I would only keep enough cash in your account to pay your bills. Professional investors keep their excess cash in short term treasury bills or invest it. In financial records it falls under cash and cash equivalents

content.text: Should I invest my emergency fund or not?

replies.text: If your salary is 100k, theyll match the first 3k at 11 and the next 2k at 21. TLDR Contribute 5, or 5k, per year to get your company to match an additional 4k total.

You need to contribute 5 of salary to get full match of 4 of salary. You get dollar for dollar match up to contributions of 3, beyond this you get 0.50 on every dollar contributed. The table below shows the match versus contribution Contribution Match 0 0 1 1 2 2 3 3 4 3.5 5 4 Often the match is evaluated on a per paycheck basis. In this case, to get a 4 match on your full annual salary, you need to contribute at least 5 of every paycheck. If you try to front load contributions into your first 12 paycheck you would only get a match of 4 of those 12 paychecks and no further match for remaining paychecks in the year. However, some companies will have a trueup match where they will match based on total annual contributions rather than just per paycheck contributions.
And frankly, stick with the simple things Equity ETFs will do you nicely. If this is confusing you, dont get fancy with other shit.

Yes, you have maxed the employer match with 7 of your income going into the 401K, but keep in mind that 7 is not enough to secure a comfortable retirement unless there is a pension or additional contributions to retirement savings, like IRA, Roth IRA. 15 of gross income is recommended as a minimum if you can afford it. I was not able to afford maxing tax deferred retirement savings or even 15 until I was mid40s.

I invest in precious metals. First, if youre not into collectible coins as a hobby, you should just buy one thing. Kilo bars for silver or oz bars for gold are great and much easier to liquidate in bulk than a bunch of random coins and collectibles. Second, only buy the dip. Gold and silver go up and down just like any other commodity based on supply and demand. In the long run, they may or may not outpace the rate of inflation. If you buy near historical highs, it may take many years to recoup your investment. If you buy near historical lows, you can reliably make pretty good returns. I think a lot of novice precious metals investors get FOMOed into buying near or at historical highs and end up making really bad investments. Dont fall into this trap. Buy when prices are low and nobody is interested.

Yep, precious metals act as a universal foreign currency. Yes a person could try and stash some foreign currency just in case their home currency experiences something like Venezuela. But it might be easier to just stash some gold and then exchange it for which ever currency didnt get impacted. For example if the US goes to war with China both of those currencies will likely take a hit look at what initially happened to both Ukraine and Russia. In that scenario there is also a good chance that countries allied to those nations like Britain, Canada, and other NATO European countries will also have their currencies impacted. So if I stocked up on some of those foreign currencies I would still likely be impacted by inflation but if I held gold it would still retain its purchasing power around the world and thus would be worth the new inflated US dollar price. As compared to the set amount of dollars that I might have saved in my savings account. Now Venezuela was a unique circumstance with so much hyperinflation that they couldnt sell their gold for their own currency because there simply wasnt enough money in circulation to cover the increase. That meant they were forced into literally using foreign currency or the precious metals themselves to buy things. That wont ever likely happen in the US because there will almost always be enough physical paper money somewhere in the world to exchange precious metals back into USD it is the world reserve after all. In essence that gold could work its way through the banks to somewhere like India or Mexico etc where they would send back some of the USD they have been holding onto in exchange for it. Thats why having some small percent of a persons net worth in silvergold is a good idea

There are some people who are perpetually stingy, and you would have to justify a 0.01 annual fee for your services, but if you can address the psychological factor of mistrust or overvaluation of your services, you will have much greater leeway and more options to obtain the better return that your client claims to want. I think its time to have a lunch with the dude, explain riskadjusted returns, detail the options that youve been able to research, and how they fall short of his requirements. While I can never say 100 for sure, I would be willing to bet a lot that a solution for this guys preferences does not exist, and could not exist. TBills are THE GOTO for risk free return. If there was a passive product that was TBill returns 2.0 for no additional risk or effort, then NO ONE WOULD EVER INVEST IN TBILLS. This other solution would be the only solution, and probably would impact the entire market, since now, return is not measured against the riskfree rate, but the riskfree rate plus 2.0. Or, maybe it exists, but has so much additional cost that you end up netting less than the TBill rate. But the idea of risk free but more than the risk free rate is contrary to the base assumptions of the economic principles of supply and demand. Its possible the guy is dumb as a bag of rocks, but likely he knows this. And if he knows it, but is still asking, then 1 hes an asshole and is just taking the piss out of you, or 2 hes making you justify your returns and cost of services versus this unreasonable benchmark, with the hopes of bidding you down. All you can really do is offer the products and services that would be the best fit, at a reasonable cost of service, let him choose, and then get him to confirm that choice in writing.

replies.text: You can short the call any time before the call expires. But the complexity is about whether you should do it or not. If you are already assigned the short call is covered by shares. replies.text: CLOs are structured products. They are made up of the pieces of bank loans. JAAA is a really low risk credit fund because it owns the safest parts of bank loans. OXLC is an equity position of a fund that invests in the riskiest possible parts of bank loans. BKLN just owns the whole damn loan.
removed

OXLC and ECC are CEFs that use leverage on top of CLOs. There are now CLO ETFs, which may not be mentioned in income factory. JAAA, JBBB, CLOI and CLOZ. Without the leverage the pure CLO ETFs are less volatile than the CEFs and also Senior loan ETFs like BKLN and SRLN,

I would imagine Senior Loans would have less risk. A good way to figure out which is more risky, is to look to what sort of yield the underlying assets are yielding. A higher yield would suggest higher risk, because creditors want to be rewarded for the extra risk.
BKLN SRLN have 56 vol over the past five years. OXLC and ECC have 37 and 27. You can find this information on morningstar.

Thanks I guess where I was getting tripped up was the fact that CLOs just contain a group of senior loans and high yield bonds? Would think more loan diversification would be less risky. Seeing that it could be also structure and liquidity.

Ah thank you! I missed that it was a CEF with leverage that makes sense. Except below Of course, that is good news for us Income Factory investors, because it is the equity tranche in these CLOs that we are interested in as candidates for our portfolios. Two closedend funds that I have held in my own Income Factory for several years with good results are Oxford Lane Capital OXLC and Eagle Point Credit ECC, both of which invest in the equity of CLOs. In fact, they were the first two closedend funds to introduce CLO equity investing to the retail investment market, it previously having been limited to the institutional investing realm. Excerpt From The Income Factory Steven Bavaria This material may be protected by copyright.

Yeah but lets take TLT, much lower yield, but has gone up 1.52 over the last year, compared with OXLC which has gone up 1.66 over the last year. This is not including the 19.6 div for OXLC and 3.93 for TLT.
CLOs do not just contain a group of senior loans and high yield bonds. They may contain senior, junior, and equity tranches. And those CEFs you listed additionally use leverage.

TLT is long Treasury duration and no spread risk. Bank loans are no Treasury duration and long spread risk. CLOs are whatever they want to be. OXLC is an equity position in a CLO fund. It is like the farthest you could possibly get from TLT while still being sort of fixed income. Comparing yields like that makes no sense. Comparing price return like that makes no sense. Theyre nowhere close to the same thing and they arent supposed to look alike, so its no surprise that they dont.

TLT holds long term treasuries which have a long duration, and the yield curve is currently inverted. TLT has a great deal of duration risk. Yields have gone down, maybe that explains them both being up? Someone call uhydrocyanide

Sure I just was pointing out that because the yield is much lower and the fund has performed terribly over the past years, so just looking at the yield isnt a great metric to decide whats a more risky investment.

It is more like you might want to compare similar durations. If your average Senior Loan is 2 years for example, you might do better to compare it to 2 year notes, than 20 year bonds. TLT is pretty beat up, but if rates go down, it could appreciate wildly.

Senior loans means bank loans. They are almost all floating rate notes and have basically zero Treasury duration and long credit duration. Bank loans suck out loud for things like credit crises where rates fall but the lack of duration means loan prices do not rise, and the lower Treasury rates reduce the loan coupon and spreads rise pushing loan prices down significantly. BKLN lost 20 fast during the start of Covid.

replies.text: The obvious answer is whatever you can afford. The smart answer is at least contribute what your employer matches. So if they match UP TO 5 then contribute 5. But if you need more money then contribute what you can afford.

Personal finance is unfortunately extremely personal. But some considerations What can you live on? What does your personal daytoday and monthtomonth budget work? How much money does it take to survive? To also do things you enjoy? To be happy? What does your security situation look like? What would happen if you lose your job? Do you have a safety net or do you need to provide your own? Whats your emergency fund look like? What are you financial goals? Can your money sit around waiting until retirement until you need it? Or will there be spending or purchases you want to make before that where you will need liquidity? Housing, cars, children, school, etc. When youre early in life and your career, increasing your earning potential is almost always going to beat out your saving rate. What opportunities do you have or are you interested in for investing in yourself? Will you need liquid resources to take advantage of stuff like additional school, training programs, moving for better job opportunities, etc? At your age and income, to be honest I would really not be worrying about maximizing tax benefits or looking at retirement. I would be focusing on how to best invest in myself and my earning potential. Take some of the lowhanging fruit like your Roth IRA if you can comfortably do so, but its a secondary or even tertiary concern. Your primary worry should be setting up the skills, training, schooling, and career to maximize your lifetime earnings. Once that is established then worry about the savings part.
Sounds like youve thought it through and this would give you a great head start. Theres way worse things you could do with the money.

Max is dumb and misleading. You could theoretically invest your entire paycheck into the 401k. Just invest up to the they match, and call it a day. Retirement is important, but so is living your life now and obviously paying your bills.

The general answer is fully funded emergency fund, then Roth 401k, then Roth IRA maxed, then HSA if available, then 529 if you have kids, then index funds, then high yield savings account. If you can do all that youll have 2030 million when you retire.

Putting my finger into the wind... maybe just keep doing the Roth and keep the HYSA pumping until you get a match and more tax savings with higher income later, or stay with a low percentage. But youve figured out you can slide the contributions around as you please so if you do it 6 months you can always change your mind. That can be useful if you have some uncertainty.
If theres no Roth 401k option, you need to figure out your marginal tax rate. It is likely to be lower than your expected rate in retirement
I was not i will rather max my Roth every year if you can
Is retiring early something you may be interested in? Throwing everything into a tax advantaged account you essentially cant touch until youre 60 isnt necessarily the correct answer for everyone
Yes

I do that. I save some money at the end of the year, then set my 401k contributions to 90 thats the highest my plan allows and get to the limit early in the year. I do that because if I were to get laid off or such, Id probably take a break and maybe wouldnt have a 401k to contribute to for the rest of the year. Plus money put in earlier has more time to benefit from the tax advantages. On the other hand, maybe my next job would have a 401k with matching, in which case Id miss out on that matching for a year. So maybe its a wash. You said you dont have matching me neither so this doesnt apply to you, but for anyone else reading, note that usually they only match up to x of your MONTHLY salary, and if you go beyond that in a given month, you dont get matched for the excess unless they do an end of year true up, which is sometimes done.
If there is no match max the Roth first, then traditional, then 401k.
If your taxes are low consider a roth 401k if thats an option. Itd be nice to have 40 years of tax free growth.
Yes

What I personally do is fill up all the tax advantaged space that is available to me my IRA is a Roth and my 401k most years has been traditional. I am now 40 and very comfortable. I wish I had more Roth dollars as a way to avoid penalties when I retire at age 4648. Even if you dont get a match it typically makes sense to invest in your 401k if you are able. If your 401k doesnt have a Roth option look at doing a back door Roth. If your 401k options suck, make sure to roll your accounts to an IRA when you leave various jobs.
The answer is yes. If you can afford do it.

Id say probably not. Id max your Roth, then open a brokerage account and invest as much as you can afford in it. This might cause tax issues in the future, but only when you get distributions dividends or when you sell. If your 401k has decent options, you might want to invest in it, but they rarely do, especially ones that dont have any employer match. Those are usually the ones with the high fees and small selection.
While not advice on what to do, kudos on starting your journey towards retirement already! Future you will thank you. Disclosures

At a minimum contribute what you need to so that you get the full employer max. The contributions are pretax which means yes they are taken out, but not subject to taxes. And yes while is coming out of your paycheck the impact being pretax will not be as bad. You will be fine. Then after a year, increase your contribution to the full amount. However, the absolute best thing to do is just contribute now the maximum to your 401k. And live within your means. Its not what you earn, but what you keep.. GL. Do this know and you will be retired by 40.

replies.text: Ideally, you do both to their full extent. You definitely dont skip any 401k matching, but free money is free money, and you should get all you can. Is there a minimum holding period for the stock? I will say that ideally, youre maxing out 401k, IRA, and ESPP every year. That entails saving a much larger percentage of your income.

Check on minimum holding period. A friend in a different industry had no holding period and would just buy as much as he could and dump it as soon as he could for the gains. Almost always a gain, and right into VTI for general safety

Taxes are the reason. I do my retirement investing in the 401k, and treat my ESPP as a short term savings plan with a guaranteed return if I sell it as soon as I get it. If you sell before a year has past, you pay the income tax rate. If you hold for a year, it is capital gains tax rate.
Do as much as the company will match in the 401k. I personally would not do the ESPP right now. I want cash for when this bubble bursts.

If you sell before a year has past, you pay the income tax rate. If you hold for a year, it is capital gains tax rate. This only applies to any gains you might get from the date of purchase, it is no different than any stock purchase and doesnt really specifically apply to ESPP. I dont know why people keep repeating this like its something that specifically applies to ESPP. What is actually specific to ESPP is the discount you get will always be taxed as income. The only minor difference is qualifying vs nonqualified disposition, which calculates the discount part differently, which can save you a bit of taxes, but the discount is always taxed as income, doesnt matter how long you wait.
So Im putting some into a HYSA right now, ideally Id be better off putting that money into this ESPP and aiming to hold for a least a year?

I max out my ESPP and sell immediately when the shares from that clear. With the setup my company has it is a guaranteed 15 gain, sometimes much more when the stock is going up. The interest on that HYSA will be taxed as income so the same as selling the shares from the ESPP immediately if comparing tax treatment. So, no reason to not just sell immediately for me. If my company had a mandatory holding period I would probably contribute less though. I personally dont like holding stock in a company I work for. Downturns get magnified and if I am laid off due to market conditions then I am also likely taking losses on those ESPP shares. But, everyones situation is different so just something to consider. EDIT I treat my ESPP gains as just a part of my total compensation.

You never go long leveraged ETFs. You want to be long, you short the levered short ETF. You want to be short you short the levered long ETF. If you knew how these ETFs worked this would be obvious. Some people even do both for beautiful income generating sideways action.

One I recently saw with Nvidia and NVDL is that Nvidia kept running but NVDL had a massive sell limit order on it that stopped the rise like a brick wall. Could be something similar here where its more effective due to some timing considerations
probably due to assignment and you only pay interest on a short if it exceeds your cash or it is a hard to borrow security.
I noticed my shares of SQQQ are also loaned out.
Maybe the cost to borrow SPXS is the same as the cost to borrow SPY, but you only need to borrow a third as many shares to get the same effect.

Its right in the prospectus of all levered ETFs including single inverse. Its commonly called the volatility drag If the underlier goes up by 50 say from 100 to 150. The single inverse goes down by 50 from 100 to 50. The next day the underlier returns to the original level of 100. But the inverse only needs to return the inverse of that downward PERCENTAGE move. Or 13rd. So youre at 501.33 66.6. The levered ETFs have it even worse. The problem is built into the compounding function of the return and is equal to 12volatilty2. Where that volatility itself includes the leverage.

I see what you mean, if leveraged ETF goes wrong direction or sideways, even if the underlying ETF returns to previous high, leveraged ETF will fall short of that, called slippage. So if youre not absolutely certain of the shortterm direction, its better to short the inverse ETF to minimize such slippage. Nice trick.

Why are you OK with this Shares of Vans and The North Face owner VF Corporation slid Monday as JPMorgan put the apparel giant on its Negative Catalyst Watch list. JPMorgan analysts told clients after field work and discussions with management, they cut their estimate for VFs fiscal 2025 earnings per share. The analysts pointed to wholesale challenges with The North Face, and ongoing traffic headwinds across brands. JPMorgan analysts wrote in a note to clients that after recent fieldwork and management access, they cut their fiscal 2025 earnings per share EPS estimate to 65 cents, which they noted was 35 below the Wall Street consensus. The analysts based that on an 8 yearoveryear decline in revenue, also worse than consensus forecasts. Ill add that Im not saying just because JPM says its bad, its bad. But wanted to get your take on why its not bad. Why not just wait till after Q2 print to buy to see where things shake out. How did you get comfortable. Summary V.F. Corp has experienced fluctuations in its financial performance over the past four fiscal years, showing growth in revenue but facing challenges with declining net income. The companys EBITDA and operating income have varied significantly, while balance sheet metrics have seen declines. Margins and ratios have been mixed, with a notable drop in net profit margin. VFC has faced both positive and negative news in the market and is exposed to diverse risks across operational, regulatory, macroeconomic, competitive, technological, and ESG factors. Key Financial Insights Revenue increased from 9.24 billion in 2020 to 11.61 billion in 2023 but declined to 10.45 billion in 2024. Net income dropped significantly from positive figures to a loss of 968.88 million in 2024. Gross profit margins remained stable, ranging from 41 to 52. Positive free cash flow in most years, except for 2023. Historical volatility of 58 indicates moderate stock price volatility compared to the market. Risk Factors Operational risks from supply chain disruptions and quality control issues. Regulatory risks related to trade policies, labor regulations, and environmental standards. Macroeconomic risks including economic downturns, currency fluctuations, and inflation. Competitive risks due to industry competition and evolving consumer preferences. Technological risks from cybersecurity threats and the need for digital investments. ESG risks impacting brand reputation and consumer perception. Conclusion Given the mixed financial performance, market sentiments, and diverse risks facing V.F. Corp, it is recommended to hold the stock for now. Investors should closely monitor future earnings reports, risk management strategies, and industry trends before making any significant buying or selling decisions.

Im bearish on it. Zoomies and alphas dont have nealy the same cereal consumption habits of Millennials and cereal has fallen vastly out of favor and pop cultural icon status from its peak in the 90s. Kelloggs has also been desperate to maintain profits and has resulted in cereal experiencing some of the highest inflation and shrinkflation that would make my waistline blush. General Mills Kellogs has also lost the cereal duopoly from the 90s and theres now a ton of competition. Rather rarely are people buying Kellogg brands these days, let alone cereal to begin with. If you read Kelloggs financial reports, they pretty much routinely state that cereal sales are down and falling. I suspect this was a big driver for the spinoff is that theyve continued to decline, quite substantially. The upside? Well, the profit margins on cereal are obscene so they only have to sell a few boxes a week to make , and they can keep raising prices till a box of Honeycombs Harry Potter is 30box I think the best case to put them into is managed decline. Maybe they can hire some TiKTok Influencers to peddle cereal and get it to become a hot desirable meme amongst the zoomers or something. But if they arent successful, its not going to be looking good.

My thesis is very simplified 1. Spinoffs are usually hated and disliked by the market for being unloved part of the original company. I genuinely recommend listening to Greenblatts audiobook about his experience in wallstreet. 2. This is a spinoff to a very old company. These type of spinoffs I find special cause they are rare and present a unique opportunity to enter at a very discounted price. 3. Insider buying. Insiders sell their stock for a variety of reasons but they buy it for only one if they think the stock will go up Peter Lynch

ACHR is actively working with regulators to meet safety standards, which is crucial for the tech to scale. As for the use cases, its more than just a replacement for helicopters. While early adoption may focus on premium, shortdistance travel like between airports and city centers, the longterm vision is urban air mobility thats more affordable, ecofriendly, and efficient. Think of it as turning a 45minute drive through traffic into a 10minute flightless time, less congestion, and zero emissions.

Air ambulance and emergency response if they can work out range issues. Smaller future designs could serve the small light aircraft market. Going full futurist, it could be used to deploy package delivery drones fly over an area and drop the drones that guide the packages down, release, and return to the mothership. What sets them apart from the others is the fixed wing design that provides safety in the event of some failure something helicopters dont have and the improved efficiency in flight since the wing can provide lift during forward operation. I love the potential with this tech. If it happens, it will be revolutionary. But, you could build the perfect eVTOL and there are basic challenges that appear significant. For example Parking In dense urban areas, there are multilevel parking garages that would not be easily accessible for a flying vehicle except for the roof. You can pack cars in there, but there will be very limited landing space. Piloting Alot of bad drivers out there, and this will require laymen to think in 3D about moving through the world. Crashing at 300ft has different consequences from crashing on the ground. Logistics Im not an expert so this may be different in other places, but in MA helicopters currently dont file flight plans and operate according to basic rules e.g., flight deck, nogo zones like airports, etc.. Throw thousands of yokels into the mix and that becomes untenable. Air traffic control would not be insurmountable, but it would be a new and potentially complex regime. Insurance It took most carriers years to insure Teslas when they first came out, and those are just cars with different motors. It will take some time for them to figure out affordable consumer flyingmachine insurance none of these things are unsolvable, but together they make me skeptical that this is close to being commercially viable at scale.

You bring up some solid points, and yeah, the eVTOL sector has its challenges, but thats part of what makes it so exciting. A lot of these issueslike parking, air traffic, and insuranceare being tackled headon, and the groundwork is being laid right now. Heres how things are shaping up 1. Vertiports Landing Companies are starting with dedicated landing pads on rooftops and helipads, and the idea is to eventually build out multilevel vertiports. Itll take time, but the strategy is there. 2. Pilots for Now, Automation Later Most eVTOLs will be piloted like helicopters at first, but as tech and regulations evolve, we could see automated systems take over. Redundant safety features are already in place to keep things secure. 3. Air Traffic Management Companies are working closely with the FAA to roll out a controlled, stepbystep integration into urban airspace. Its not going to be an overnight switch to thousands of eVTOLs, but a gradual rampup. 4. Insurance Evolution Youre spot oninsurance will be tricky, but this is something weve seen before with early electric vehicles. Insurers are already getting involved, and as eVTOLs prove themselves, the insurance market will adjust. These are big hurdles, no doubt, but if it all comes together, its going to be revolutionary. Plus, with high short interest and recent movement, we might not have to wait as long as people think to see some action.

TLDR Early March 2020 Hesitated to invest in masks due to market chaos. A trusted supplier offered KN95 masks, leading to first order of 250,000 masks. Market was chaotic stories of buyers offering cash directly at factories. First order sold quickly, yielding 172,600 in profit. Second shipment 1 million masks sold, earning 1.57 million in profit. Third shipment 1.06 million masks and 20,000 gowns sold, adding 1.08 million in profit. Total profit from first three shipments 2.83 million. Fourth shipment 5.15 million masks planned, costing 11.12 million. U.S. government regulation and market collapse caused 5 million loss, wiping out previous profits. Overall, despite 13.87 million in total sales, ended with significant losses.

I know the company has been through a lot over the past few years. Im not saying this stock will definitely go up, but I think the chance of a turnaround is mispriced. On average, this play could be profitable. Of course, I cant go into too much detail in a WSB post. Its not about predicting exactly what will happen anyone who claims they can predict the stock market is probably just kidding themselves. But I believe youd come out ahead if we ran this scenario a bunch of times.

I see the biggest opportunities when the entire market has a solid opinion about something. Thats where you can find prices that are irrational or mispriced. It doesnt mean going against the crowd is always a winning strategy, but if you just follow what every retail trader is doing, you wont get great returns. For those looking to play it safe, ETFs like the SP 500, QQQ, or MSCI World make a lot of sense and can provide decent returns. When I think about the next 10 years, Im not too sure what will happen. Im more focused on the next 13 years. Sure, you can jump on the NVIDIA train and the whole AI hype, but while AI is a hot topic right now, weve seen four waves of AI before, each bringing new revolutionary advancements. Im skeptical about how smart these LLMs really are, and there are many other forms of AI that have potential too. Additionally, NVIDIAs valuation is influenced by factors like demand for gaming GPUs, data center growth, and the overall semiconductor market trends. However, with a 3 trillion market cap, Im curious to see if they can maintain that level. It seems heavily tied to momentum and hype, and we all know hype can fizzle out. If youre looking to play it safe over the next year, maybe consider investing in a few broad and diversified ETFs, and perhaps look into some China and India indexes, too. Overall, I think investing in Intel could be a good addition to your portfolio, but I wouldnt recommend putting your entire portfolio into it.

I hope youre right, Im not one of those who takes pleasure in a good company gone bad. But their track record is shit. They went from industry leader to repeat laughingstock in 10 years. I know a lot of Bay Area engineers and none would touch a job at Intel for any amount of money itd be career suicide for them. The deck is stacked against them. Their valuation may be book look up goodwill if you want to see whats written in the book but they are priced at book value for a company that was expected to be an industry leader in about 10 different areas. Their future plans dont include industry leadership in any area and they are exiting more than half of the markets theyve been working in and borrowing money to do XX billion capex in. Its no joke to spend 20B on capex in the hope of entering a market, and then exit that market. Its no joke to do that in 5 different markets in 10 years. Its no joke to put out a quarterly report showing you lost 9 billion in 3 months, after your turnaround was supposed to have been under way for a year and a half. As an investor you have the option to invest in other companies, ones that dont flush 100 billion down the toilet. The idea that theyve gotten away with it for this long is not a bull pitch it means there are a set of entrenched managers there who think its OK to run their business this way. Ill be interested when the stock price hits 1012 and I start hearing that people want to work there, because I think thats about where youd start seeing a chance for meaningful upside from a turnaround. Im not into investing in overhyped stocks that have already skyrocketed. Look at NVDAits insanely overpriced because everyone and their mom is buying it, thinking the line will just keep going up forever. These companies have PE ratios over 60, which is ridiculous. Its starting to feel like the Dotcom bubble, but this time with AI. Honestly, outside of a few specific uses, AI is kind of useless in its current state and nowhere near as smart as people think. With the massive investments going into AI, the returns needed to justify them are just unrealistic. Sure, in the short term, the AI boom might keep pushing tech stocks and the market up, but once the returns dont materialize fast enough, the bubble is going to pop. Im not saying AI is a total flop, but were not there yet, and the market is way too impatient. Meanwhile, Intel is in a much better spot strategically. Theyre still super important for the U.S., consumer PCs, and cloud computing, and theres still huge demand for energyefficient chips. Over the next two years, I think Intel will outperform NVIDIA by a lot.
