I applaud your comment. very transparent. I have not used cerebras so I was just going by the marketing on their webpage. What I am saying is that the information and their comparisons are very outdated as Microsoft has aggressively opened the throughput for the OpenAI models. One thing I will quibble with is that api limit is related to inference speed because it is throughput. In a way it is expected throughput as well. Heres what I mean. Previously when you used LLMs in Azure you would get a warning for tokens you could generate per minute if you went over the limit and then outright rate limiting would 404 your requests going forward. Now, to your point latency is what we are really talking about here. What I can tell you is that each model has its own latency expectations that Microsoft never publishes because if youre on a pay as you go service you are effectively on a shared service. What I can tell you is that 4 was terrible, 4turbo was a little better, 4o is a lot better and 4omini is perfect. In terms of latency. 4omini is a smaller param model. Tokens are complex especially in an enterprise environment. I am passing thousands of tokens through expecting thousands of tokens back on complex queries. With that said, if you really are comparing apples to apples small model versus small moel I think their claims fall apart and thats my point.

Nobody uses Azure on a shared or dedicated service with a single GPU. Youre missing the point of how this works. GPUs are typically connected through NVLINK and networking, which increases throughput and reduces latency. With more powerful and interconnected GPUs, latency decreases, and throughput improves. In this way, throughput and latency are related, especially when processing complex models. Since the new GPTo1, many factors influence speed and throughput behind the scenes, and they do indeed relate.

Training will never be on par with inference until models can be trained instantly, which is just a fact. But youre right that workloads are shifting more towards inference. That said, the models doing the inference still need to be trained. Training is timebased, while inference is an ongoing, aggregate usage over time. As chips get faster, training times will drop, and inference will grow. But with future data and models being larger and more complex, who knows how training will pan out. At some point, training will be good enough and modular training will come into play, allowing realtime updates, while inference handles the queries and keeps adding to that longterm memory.

They really shook their developers down with the announcement of per download charges, and that scared a lot of those developers away. They obviously realized they tried to boil the frog too fast, walked back their decision to monetize downloads and pivoted CEOs, but I dont think anything they do will heal the brand damage. Developers with current projects are kind of stuck as its a huge undertaking to completely rewrite your game on another platform, but how are they going to attract new developers and sustain long term growth when theyve put the development community on edge? I dont think they will ... I think weve seen the peak of Unity and its all dead cat bounces from here.

Genshin Impact and ZZZ are built on Unity, but upon the news of Unitys pricing fiasco they started hiring game engineers out the ass. The entire exec suite has been swapped out since the announcement was rolled back. I dont really buy the once the trust is broken it is gone forever in the context of companies, which are made up of everchanging humans with different evolving perspectives.

Genshin Impact and ZZZ are built on Unity, but upon the news of Unitys pricing fiasco they started hiring game engineers out the ass. Either theyre going to make their own in house engine or switch to Unreal. Theres not many studios running inhouse engines these days. Even CD Projekt Red who had a solid inhouse engine switched to Unreal. That being said theres no reason for me to see why the past actions of the former CEO will affect the new Unity 6. To add, you dont just switch engines on an already built game. Genshin is unity and they cant switch till they release their next game. Its more likely they incorporate Unity 6 features into their already built games.
Or they will reevaluate and decide to stay with Unity.

There is no metric for trust. Perhaps some indie developers you know and the reddit comments from people who dont even make games. But big corps with their mobile and VR projects dont care about anything other than revenues. The engine is also easy to learn and train for staffs with good documentation. Unity 6 is missing only that nice LOD generation feature of Unreal 5. In exchange it offers competitive pricing and the dev team has been listening very well to their userbase. If Godot was so good, Unity will be screwed hard by now but from what we have seen, it just serves as a cheap, nonintuitive, slow and buggy alternative with a mental head lead dev. I hope it gets acquired by META or MFST actually, but the company and their product are not going away anytime soon.

I said this in another comment but if your customer base are largely independent studios you arent changing any hearts or minds by swapping out the suit. The market has a short memory but many of these studios projects are measured in years, with some taking half a decade or more. Only the market gives a shit about the csuite. Most customers arent interacting with the people youre referring to. The devs that have already left the platform arent coming back and an entire generation of game developers now have a tribal dont use unity use godot mentality. I think you fail to appreciate how hard gamers feel they are oppressed.

Several misconceptions youre making. Given that Unitys pricing restructure was going to specifically affect mobile games, especially ones like Genshin, its likely that Hoyo would do a cost benefit analysis and deduce that rebuilding the engine would ultimately save money compared to Unitys insane pricing. BUT even moreso, its that more games in the future are going to avoid Unity due to this shift in public perception and developer persepction around the engine.
sure there is. subcription churn is a reasonable metric for trust. i havent checked their subscription numbers going back several quarters, but i expect there has not been huge negative impacts.
the exodus to godot is overstated and overblown. godot is still far behind Unity. Studios didnt change engines, hobbyists did.

I think you touched on an important point as well its not easy to swap game engines since projects are measured in years. Many Unity users begrudging continued to use the engine despite the run time fee fiasco. I suspect they will reevaluate their needs when their projects are released but I dont expect studios to be acting irrationally because of a moral grudges... IMO a game developer setting out today deciding to use Godot to create the same types of mobile games Unity is capable of is not a serious developer. Godot is not a 11 port of everything Unity or UE is capable of, at least not yet.

Yes but everything youve said would affect these games has since been walked back. It is likely future games will avoid it but I think given the changes at the top of the company, it doesnt seem likely that the in the long term Unity will be phased out. If the pricing structure was seen to completion I have no doubt that games like Genshin may have been rebuilt however I still find that unlikely, but given that the pricing structure was nipped in the bud, I dont see it affecting games currently using Unity. To add, thered be no reason to implement new unity features to those games as Unity releases them.
An they would reevaluate that view regularly. They may have change their minds since then.

All we have to talk about are anecdotes anyway, but my point is that gamers and devs are some of the worst, most emotional, irrational consumers in existence. Studios are less and less of the overall pie every year, a trend that will continue as barriers to publishing continue to be solved by new distribution mediums. Good will goes a long way in this market. Again, im not saying Unity will fail as a company. But they will not be an industry leader.

Anyone who genuinely thinks devs whole sale swapped engines for ongoing development is on crack. I dont think the full effects of the Unity fiasco have been felt for exactly that reason. I think that gives Unity some time to ameliorate some of those relationships, but I definitely believe theres more than one studio making the decision to use Unreal for their next title.

You fail to recognize that the walking back doesnt un burn the bridges that Unity burnt. They just made a change that puts an entire project at risk. Now during the decision making process for games, Unity will be viewed as a potential liability. Given that they already risked making one change, they will likely risk making another at some point. Watch and learn.

This entire argument lives in the fantasy that because it was never enacted there was no lasting fallout in trust, like the act of replacing a ceo and walking back a bad policy had no impact. Thats a stretch. Unity 6 may be successful but I dont see Unity being the industry leader, ever.
They were never industry leaders anyway, that was Unreal engine and still is.

I think you fail to take into account the changes at the top. If there wasnt a new CEO I would be more inclined to agree with you. I understand it doesnt in burn those bridges but it is an extremely well established engine a majority of developers have experience with. I may be wrong of course but I dont think it is as cut and dry as you are making it out to be. Theres ample opportunity for them to grow or fail again.

I think it all comes down to what we think game studios decisions will be. Unity is a well established engine. At worst youre looking at studios moving to Unreal but I dont see many studios developing their own engine. Thats a big risk that a vast majority of developers probably wont take. Same outcome either way if they move to Unreal of course. I just dont see many companies totally jumping ship if they have a lot of talent that has experience with unity. I could of course be wrong but we are speculating here.

Yeah they arent gonna magically fix their financial issues due to having a new CEO. They COULD make a turn around, but thats incredibly unlikely given the damage theyve caused to their brand and reputation.

Well, Im not sure if its gonna be these earnings although I dont have high expectations or other future earnings, but Im fairly sure Tesla will come crashing down, and that eventually reality is gonna catch up with them. Right now, theyre still riding on their name and the bonus of being the first big player. But China is catching up, and theyre doing so rapidly, which is gonna put a lot more pressure on Tesla in the chinese market. South Korean companies are head and shoulders above Tesla when it comes to procuding EVs, the difference in quality and technology is astounding. Eventually, that quality is gonna prevail and its gonna flush Tesla out of certain market segments. Now, lets talk about Europe First of all, the quality of Teslas is horrible. Like, really, really horrible, really poorly processed. And that becomes especially evident if you are used to european or particularly german car makers. Thats one thing. Something like a Polestar running on Volvos platform is gonna give you a much higher quality vehicle at a similar price. But lets go back to Germany in particular the german car manufacturers have collectively fucked the transition to EVs theyre slow and sluggish in the transition, theyre hurting because the car industry is experiencing hardship as a whole, and theyre consistently slipping in terms of development. Now, why is that not a good sign of Tesla? Well, thats because theyve been doing poor to an extent that has the entirety of Europe rethink the previously agreed on goal of banning new ICE vehicles by 2035. If they void that agreed goal, it means prolonged and stronger competition from ICE vehicles on the market, the transition to EVs is gonna commence slower which in turn gives other car manufacturers more time to catch up in terms of their product and in terms of their infrastructure. As for everything about Tesla thats not directly related to their EV business well, how have those things been going so far? Nothing but smoke and mirrors at this point.

Its too soon to bet against Tesla, but the stock will crash at some point. Tesla is still priced like a tech company, but 80 of Teslas revenue comes from selling cars. Tech companies trade at a high multiple because, they can scale simply by adding compute. You can write software once, and sell it millions of times. Its more complicated than that, but you get the idea. Teslas valuation is based on the hope that everyone will be licensing Teslas FSD, battery designs, and other technologies at some point. Otherwise, the only way Tesla can scale is to build huge factories and hire armies of skilled workers. Young tech companies are expected to grow market share by 20 per year, and established tech giants are expected to have margins far higher than Teslas. I dont know if the Cybertruck will turn out to be a failure, but it is certainly a PR headache, and a distraction. Tesla might be better served by updating its aging cash cows, the Model Y and Model 3. The humanoid robot is an embarrassing joke by any metric and a further distraction. Elon himself has said that Teslas valuation only makes sense if full autonomy is achieved. So far, it looks like Elons gamble on using visiononly for FSD against the advice of his engineers, has backfired. Waymo and Cruise have arguably pulled ahead of Tesla in realworld autonomy. Elon had better pull a pretty big rabbit out of his hat with the robotaxi announcement. A Google engineer was once quoted as saying Were 90 of the way there with autonomous driving. Now we just need to finish the last 90. His point was that the remaining edge cases left to solve were so difficult that they might take decades. It may be that these remaining problems cannot be solved without radarlidar. If that is the case, then Tesla is in trouble.

It makes it an imperfect comparison, but the point that younger companies have an advantage in new markets is not moot. Just look at the average age of magnificent seven stocks. Toyota has decades of experience with ICE cars. Their factories, engineers and marketing are all geared toward ICE and hybrid cars, and they have struggled to create a successful pure EV. Early Audi EVs sometimes displayed low oil warnings, as they had tried to reuse software and sensors from their ICE cars. Theres something to be said for starting from scratch. This lack of legacy baggage is why creative destruction is a thing. Older companies gradually get bogged down by outdated products and practices and are picked off by younger, more nimble competitors. Of course, if EV adoption continues to slow down due to range anxiety and lack of compelling products, the oldschool companies might yet win out. Hybrid sales are already picking up relative to pure EVs, which is part of why Toyota is still relevant.

Snapdragon is the QCOM CPU and uses an ARM architecture . Lunar Lake is the newest Intel CPU generation and uses the x86 architecture. Virtually all Windows programs are written for x86 CPUs so the ARM CPUs have issues running them.

What operating system will this revolutionary SoC run? Windows, right? The point is that Windows on ARM is not in a good enough shape yet for wider adoption. There are glaring compatibility issues with x86 drivers and programs. These issues are not easily solved mind you drivers cannot be emulated and developers have little incentive to port and test their driversappsgames to Windows on ARM since the userbase is tiny. Its a chicken and egg problem for WoA not something Apple had to worry about since they control the whole Mac ecosystem. All it takes is one appdrivergame not working and the hypothetical NvidiaARM laptop goes back to the store.

Why PE VC exist Over the past 50 years, huge amounts of money have piled up in the hands of big institutions like pension funds, sovereign wealth funds, and highnetworth individuals HNWI. This money has to go somewhere to grow. However, public stock markets just arent big enough to handle all this cash. If too much money floods the public market, prices would go crazy due to simple supply and demand more money chasing the same number of stocks. Its like if everyone in a huge city wanted to buy just one houseprices would skyrocket. So, these big money players needed an alternative. Thats where private markets come in, specifically Private Equity PE and Venture Capital VC VC is for startups or earlystage companies. They fund highrisk, highreward businesses hoping to strike it big. PE buys out more mature companies, often aiming to restructure and make them more profitable. Why the PE VC industry exploded PE and VC offer access to these private markets, and institutions were eager to jump in because public markets alone couldnt absorb all their money. The PE industry, in particular, has ballooned from managing 500 billion to a whopping 8 trillion in 20 years. This explosion is simply because PE firms managed to convince big institutions to pour in cash to them by selling them the promise of high returns. The problem In VC, things are looking rough. A lot of opportunists jumped into VC, promising big returns but actually delivering poor or even negative results. However, VC firms still made money off management fees, while investors were left holding the bag with bad returns. Even if PE is facing the same destiny, the bubble burst is simply people getting bad returns. Whats the unwinding? I think you have misunderstood the Unwinding. It isnt a bubble burst, it just means that eventually, investors and the public will catch on to the fact that PEVC firms may not have been as good at delivering returns as promised. The issue is that many of these firms have found ways to make themselves rich through management fees taking a cut from the funds they manage and carried interest taking a chunk of profits, but not suffering equally from losses. The risk is heavily onesidedinvestors take most of it, while the fund managers make money regardless of the results. And remember who have funds the investors from the beginning? Its common people like you and me either through pensions funds, taxes, HNWI who in their turn often have made money from being exited by PE. So its ordinary people who are left holding the bag when this is all said and done. TLDRELI5, The world has created a lot of money supple wealth, and we need places to invest it, but there isnt enough public stocks for it. People in Private Equity PE and Venture Capital VC have made money on the shared wealth we have created in society regardless of the fund returns and people are finally taking about it.

Yes, private equity PE is a bubble. Rehypothecation is a word you should be familiar withPE firms reuse collateral across multiple loans, sometimes up to 140 of their original value, expanding leverage without increasing underlying assets. When liquidity tightens or asset values drop, multiple creditors claim the same collateral, leading to forced liquidations. The industrys sizegrowing from 500 billion to 8 trillion in 20 yearshas been driven by financial engineering as you said, debtfinanced buyouts LBOs, and structured financial products akin to mortgagebacked securities MBS, such as SLABS Student Loan Asset Backed Securities, CLOs Collateralized Loan Obligations, and CMBS Commercial MBS, which all contributed to the 2008 crisis. With shadow banking providing unregulated capital, and central banks managing liquidity in complex ways 50bps cut at ATHs...?, the bubble is increasingly fragile and at risk of unraveling. Liquidity injections will keep it from collapsing for a while, but the FED will have to get increasingly more intrusive to keep assets elevated, such as using Japans creation QQE QualitativeQuantitative Easing. Its inevitable that it crashes, but if the FED pull off a soft landing is yet to be seen

And AI helps too. Or just marketing with AI on it.

Received an email saying Please dont disregard this email, this a real offer..... Followed by them saying how they want to buy my business. They had me at Please dont, so naturally I trashed the email without reading the rest of it. A few days later, I fished it out of trash, looked up the company name, discovered that they are actually aggressive in acquiring smaller projects like mine and that they grow through acquisitions. So I replied to them. Then, they asked for all my key metrics. Then they made the offer. A few phone calls to negotiated the details. Then, the due diligence process was a breeze. Then we signed. On the closing day I was sitting there refreshing my banks page to see when the wire comes in. It was taking forever, so I called them. They were like oh, yeah, I forgot to ask Mike to sign off on the wire, hold on, I think I saw him leaving for lunch let me grab him now. Like its nothing to them. Then an hour or so later the wire came in. And my low five digit account balance changed to seven digit balance after a refresh of a page. Then the panic set it. So I started another business literally a week later which a few years later I sold for seven fig to a competitor of the guys that bought this one. Different niche, so noncompete didnt apply but similar business model. Six months later I started another business, which I still have 15 years later. It was a fun ride. But I was a regard and didnt invest the money, so I pretty much live off of my current business ventures now instead of having several mil in sp500 and being semiretired, if I just werent a moron. But back then the market was in this giant sideways mode, so I just didnt believe it would grow in the time horizon for which I planned. I was wrong on both counts. The market eventually started to grow, and time horizons of young people are way too short to be realistic. The moral of the story is dont be a regard and invest. Think decades not years. Youll thank yourself later. Now Im must excuse myself to go cry a little and get back to work.

At this point, shorting or putting on DJT is an election bet. My guess is that the stock will drop hard by late September when Trump and the DJT insiders to a stock sell off when the lockup ends. Also, assuming Trump loses, DJT could drop even harder, possibly all the way to 0. I currently hold puts at 10 920, 12 927, and 7.5 11725. I sold a 15 927 for 46 capital gains, but in hindsight, I should have kept holding to ride the stocks volatility. Anyway, TLDR, DJT all the way to 0!

Per the website, As of June 25, 2024, President Trump owned 114,750,000 approximately 58.7 of the outstanding shares of Trump Media. President Trump is subject to a lockup that generally restricts the sale or transfer of his shares until the earliest of 1 six months after the closing of the Business Combination 2 the date on which the closing price of Trump Medias stock equals or exceeds 12 for any twenty trading days within any thirty trading day period commencing at least 150 days after the closing or 3 the date after the closing on which Trump Media consummates a liquidation, merger, share exchange or other similar transaction that results in all of Trump Medias stockholders having the right to exchange their equity holdings in Trump Media for cash, securities or other property. As the result of a business combination transaction the Business Combination with Digital World Acquisition Corp. completed on March 25, 2024, Trump Media became a public company and commenced trading under the symbol DJT on March 26, 2024. If my calculations are correct, then 150 days after 326 was 823, so then we start counting days where the stock closed above 12 no need to count it was every day. 20 days after 823 is this Thursday 912. In a way yes. Rates are a 0sum game. There is no to the moon. 125 bps from 475 to 350 is not the same as 350 to 225 and conversely 225 to 350 is not the same as 350 to 475. There is convexity. These are not stocks and they are not linear. OP missed the relative term discount on duration trying to catch a bull steepener after the move. You could easily get 300bps of policy rate change and 0 in the 10 over the next 1618 months. The bond market is different and being late to the party in bonds matters much more than it does in equity trading. This trade makes 0 sense from an alpha perspective and it should be unwound.

So when would you consider entering a position on TLT If you wanted long term exposure to longer dated bonds and recession insurance. Genuinely asking as this trade might not be attractive in the near term as it is trading at a fat premium but if you zoom out, its got potential.

I love tlt and edv for asset allocation and hedging. I do not think the bullshit direxon or equity option on bond funds are good ideas when there is a flat to normal sloping curve and the fed has already broadcast the direction of future policy. It takes very little to hedge equities with long duration as a pure play and that is EXACTLY why stips and zeros existinstitutional money managers use them the same way. Derivatives on these sold to retail investors should not even be legal. Youre getting taken advantage of. You cannot time exogenous shocks and thats what it takes to get large moves in long duration, you just want to own some unless its an obviously bad idea to be a buyer like when rates are near 0. Its a perfectly reasonable time to have the security in your portfolio, not the derivatives hoping for moon shots. EDV is actually a purer duration play and you can see there are really two historic events when you would have benefited greatly from the hedge GFC, COVID. These are not things you can time. Duration is a powerful, but boring tool. When to own it is a real yield question. People shouldnt expect a large move over the next year without an exogenous shock. The 6T in money market funds and excess risk assets does not flow into long duration, it flows into the front end of the curve for safety. Long rates broadcast genuine sentiment and they will move before the fed, and before a flight to safety. It was an exciting time to add the position at 5. 3.75 is normal. You really need to be at the extremes to time an aggressive rate bet as a retail investor and a flat curve is pretty much the worst time to do that, especially an otm call after a 125 basis point bullish move before the fed even blinked. The policy moves are going to change the front of the curve much more than TLTEDV, and there is limited upside in short duration.

Yeah Ive seen this and the only substantive issue, especially in the year since this report was published, may be the facility monitoring, Ill get back to that piece in a bit. Overall, and ironic considering their claims of ACHR being misleading, I find the report to be pretty deliberately misleading itself. Top line, Archer has clearly built and flown at least several completely functional Midnight airframes since that report. Regarding the USAF contract Archer has since delivered a fully functional Midnight airframe to the Air Force. Its true that they are behind Joby, but thats always been the case, and I am assuming neither the FAA Special Airworthiness Cert nor the USAF would take delivery of a scam product or vaporware at least, not a full airframe. The USAF potential order for airframes is not a substantial piece of ACHRs overall order book or operating revenue plans in any case, but I dont see why they wouldnt be able to deliver on the relatively small order if USAF continues to pursue it. They mention ACHR contracts with USAF related to autonomous flight and other highertech initiatives. I do find it likely ACHR will not continue as a leader in that space, as Jobys technology in these areas is indeed superior, as I mention in my OP. These contracts are a fraction 30M or less of the main eVTOL initiative there in any case. Highlighting these as potential losses is misleading in the context of ACHRs main business. Grizzly consistently mentions the dollar value of exercised warrants and share awards in the context of the obviouslyinflated price of August 23. While yes, those shares may be worth a considerable amount if ACHR succeeds in going to market, Grizzly leads with very large numbers attached to those share issuances while barely mentioning how unusual a price above 7 is for ACHR. Also as I addressed in OP, Grizzly talks up Joby throughout, but Jobys total share dilution is over double ACHRs total outstanding shares to this day. While there may be valid complaints about dilution, its outrageous to be in up arms over the issuances when a key competitor has done so much more. They obliquely imply that the companies investing in ACHR are doing so because theyre being given an opportunity to sell out of the company at the inflated share price. Stellantis has since continued to agree to investments in the company, with direct sharesforwork programs to ramp manufacturing. This is a pretty clear rebuttal of a number of points made by Grizzly. nbsp Regarding the manufacturing, flight videos, and overall progress being clouded ACHR has ramped up PR and specific posting of facilities and progress on the Georgia plant. Midnight clearly exists and clearly flies, including a more recent 10 minute unedited flight test video, an exact rebuttal of one of Grizzlys issues Where they posted a similar uncut Joby video. Its also a little odd that Grizzly was complaining about editing to make a flight appear longer in a video that was already only 042 seconds, which... okay? The source who claimed 2028 was Optimistic for certification is clearly not tracking how overall sector is making progress. If thats the case, Joby would be on target for 2027 at best also, and they have a complete custom ecosystem to certify, not just offtheshelf parts. Both companies, in the year following, are maintaining target times and presenting percenttocompletion that still targets 2025. It is possible still that Archers certification will be delayed to late 25 or 2026... I do find it worrying that they are still a little handwavey about their completely compliant for credit airframes being ready to go or in testing. I have addressed schedule risks several times when posting about the sector and ACHR specifically. That said, since August 23, their main Georgia plant is clearly progressing and they maintain the EOY timeline for completion as of this quarter. nbsp The claims about doing on site observation of the airport are at least interesting. However, its notable that the week they spent observing was exactly when the full size Midnight was built but not yet FAA certified. This timeframe lines up with the archer engineer saying they would have to wait as I find it rather plausible flight tests were paused between completion of the Midnight full size prototype and its airworthiness certification note that the continue to test flight daily were from prior announcements that occurred before their observational period I also have very little faith in the reports of supposed eyewitnesses when they are being asked about things by a literally activist shortseller company... Maker and Midnight are both quiet and small airframes, unique looking, true, but also short range. A full test flight could occur over the space of an hour or less, so even daily test flights may be missed routinely by people simply on the same airport grounds. Note that Grizzly did not consult or reference FAA Air Traffic Control, flight plan logs, or other possible authoritative sources for air time. Moreover, the empty facility they visited is very definitely online given that actual photo and video from the manufacturing process has been posted, and, again, at least several operational midnight airframes exist including one that USAF deemed acceptable for delivery. nbsp TO BE CLEAR I am not saying ACHR is definitely a superstar company thats going to be shitting out eVTOLs into the air taxi market next year... I just dont think that the piece published by Grizzly is a reasonable analysis.

First of all, if youre holding shares, you should be fine over a longer time horizon, this is around where we should bottom out... why ACHR is valued how it is right now Archer and JOBY, and all other eVTOL companies except EHang in china, are prerevenue companies. In other words, theyre spending money on RD but havent yet begun operations. Archer isnt actually selling or flying airframes commercially yet. As a result, traditional valuations such as PE, Dividend return, DCF, and other methods are either difficult or impossible to apply as a valuation mechanic. financial information such as cash burn rate compare to likely start of revenue generation substitute for this as a risk indicator. It does have generally nonbinding commitments for airframe sales valued at 6bn, as well as plans to selfoperate an air taxi service. Along with projected growth in the new Advanced Air Mobility sector, archer is theoretically well positioned for massive growth when operations do begin... Conversely, two major risks remain to getting operations. Most notably, type certification from the FAA saying the aircraft can fly passengers, and scaling of manufacturing supply chain and completion of main assembly line. Theres also a wider risk of a lack of infrastructure to support Air Taxis or the sector simply not catching on as something the public pays for. Essentially, the value of the company is then Possible major growth as a first mover in a new industry minus risk of catastrophic failure. Investing long term is saying Im parking money here knowing im speculating on success while short selling is saying i think the risks here are too great, and this company will fail before reaching operations. Why, specifically, its current exact value? Well, per my post, i have no idea and think its undervalued, so i am invested, but other people clearly have assessed the risk profile differently. nbsp As to why its red or green on any given day... its generally red and low priced when no catalysts or news comes out... Archer is very much on the hook to be much more concrete about its schedule, and soon, or the perceived risks grow a lot... many people are probably getting scared off by the relative lack of news given the supposedly tight timeline to start production. it goes WAY green when catalysts hit... new deals, timelines being confirmed, advances in certification progress, etc... that is, when the likelihood of future revenues increase and risks decrease and investors pile in. nbsp EOY prediction... Given the above and the fact that i am heavily invested in Oct and Jan calls. whatll happen? Basically two possible routes 1. ACHR begins for credit FAA type certification flights and proceeds quickly due to having mostly off the shelf parts i cover this vs Jobys custom build in my OP, and completes its Georgia manufacturing plant. If both of these occur by EOY, we probably go back to near 52w high 7 if not higher. 2. Any delays, setbacks, or major negative news occurs, or radio silence continues, and price continues to tank as investors look for shorter term gains and are unwilling to keep money parked in ACHR while it struggles to get running. nbsp Past EOY 24 to EOY 25 If they succeed in an entry in service date by EOY 25, that is, commercial operations begin, then we get to see an ASTSlike move in the price, as retail and institutions surge in on the hype train. This may be dampened a bit if Joby enters service earlier especially if Joby begins operations and encounters problems with operations We may see pops much earlier in 25 if nonbinding order agreements become binding as a result of Certification. 6bn in confirmed order backlog would be MASSIVE compared to 6bn in uncommitted orders. Conversely, if for credit testing begins but they faildelay for some reason, price tanks back to 3 range. If manufacturing plant has delays or failures, or production stalls due to supply chain issues, commensurate reduction in share price. nbsp Overall if you have shares you have several strategies Very long hold, as the Bull case through 2030 implies explosive potential 10x or more in share price, more if we get meme price spikes Sell on hype taking profits next time really good news comes out... then either be happy with that or rebuy when price slips between good news announcements. nbsp why do i have shorter term options? Well i have shares too, the short term options I play are very much gambling... but, as i describe above, this very speculative tech sector can see impressively insane hype spikes. Great news about beginning for credit testing or new orders or firm commitments, all trigger runs past 5 to 67. The time between now and EOY 24 is absolutely critical for the stated timeline and therefore speculative options could pay out massively. If price spikes, i also take out Strangles add puts to the mix to account for bad news and price drops.

What I find interesting that no one is talking about is how we might see Starliner fail on reentry. I was going to make a post about this earlier today, but work got in the way and now you come along with this great explainer, Ill just put my 2 cents in a comment. To the uninitiated Starliners failures were in its RCS thrusters, which basically control how its oriented and the direction its going. They got very lucky that the failure was able to be controlled enough to dock with the ISS. I am not sure if luck will be on their side again. Not only did Starliner not originally have autonomous descent software in it, but these thrusters will also control how it reenters the atmosphere. There are a few scenarios that could happen 1. They dont fail again, reentry goes off without a hitch 2. They fail in such a way that causes the reentry profile to be too steep, causing it to burn up on reentry. 3. They fail in such a way that causes the reentry profile to be too shallow, causing it to take multiple orbits to slow down enough for atmospheric capture, altering its final destination and even possibly causing scenario 2 to happen. 4. They fail in such a way that causes it to crash into the ISS. This one is much less likely from the basis that NASA is even oking it to undock, crashing into the ISS would not just endanger the lives of everyone on board, but also cause rifts in global geopolitics they dont call it the INTERNATIONAL Space Station for nothing, aint no way NASA is risking this. Scenario 1 is boring and does nothing for all of your puts. Scenario 2 and 3 I believe would cause a lot of panic selling. Boeing has reportedly been adamant about the astronauts using Starliner still despite these failures, and if its destroyed upon reentry all anyone will be talking about is holy shit Boeing almost knowingly caused another Columbia. Then again, I know more about rocket science than Ill ever know about stocks, and I only know the very basics of rocket science.

The fundamental problem with your thesis here is your making a macro call and then trying to apply it to a discrete event occurring very shortly. Even if we agreed that theres power concerns, fiscal concerns, concerns with the overall model of AI, concerns about chip manufacturing and ability Its unlikely any of that is on the ballot on the 28th. Whats going to be the concern is revenues for this quarter hitting towards the top end of expectations or exceeding it and then projections for the upcoming quarters Now maybe some of those issues feed into projections but I sort of doubt it. These are longer term problems, so Id be more willing to bet they become an issue over the next 6 to 18 months rather than in 3 days. So its a pretty regarded take to make based on the thesis. TLDR If you want to make a macro AI thesis you should put the time frame for it to play out at longer than 3 days. More like 618 months.

But GPT read and responded in 5seconds The critique youve provided rests on a few misconceptions and overlooks key aspects of AIs current trajectory and potential. 1. AI Approaches and Progress The critique dismisses the GPTML approach as a known dead end, but this perspective fails to account for the significant advancements these methods have already achieved. While its true that current AI systems are not equivalent to human intelligence or capable of fulfilling science fictionlike fantasies e.g., J.A.R.V.I.S., this was never their immediate goal. The successes of GPT3, GPT4, and similar models in natural language processing, image generation, and other domains are impressive and provide immense value across industries. 2. Exponential Investment for Linear Gains The notion of exponential investment for linear gains is not unique to AI. Most technological progress, particularly in nascent fields, requires substantial investment before significant breakthroughs are realized. The idea that AI is stagnating is contradicted by ongoing improvements in model capabilities, optimization techniques, and the emergence of new architectures that continue to push the boundaries of whats possible. 3. Business Case for AI The critique argues that AI has failed to meet investor expectations by not delivering a fully autonomous system capable of complex tasks like designing cars. However, this expectation misunderstands the nature of AI development. AI is not meant to be an allencompassing solution to every problem overnight. Incremental improvements, such as automating specific tasks, enhancing decisionmaking, and creating new products, are already transforming industries. The ultimate goals may be ambitious, but the journey itself is valuable and profitable. 4. Training Data and Resources Concerns about running out of training data or resources ignore the adaptability of AI research. Techniques like transfer learning, unsupervised learning, and more efficient model architectures help mitigate these challenges. Moreover, the development of specialized hardware, improved algorithms, and better data utilization strategies continuously address the resourceintensive nature of AI. 5. Nvidias Role While its true that tech giants are moving towards vertical integration, Nvidia remains a critical player in the AI hardware ecosystem. The dominance of CUDA, the ongoing innovation in GPU architecture, and the importance of a robust softwarehardware ecosystem are not easily replaced or replicated. Nvidias role may evolve, but it is far from obsolete. 6. Investor Expectations The critique implies that investors are disillusioned, yet the continued flow of capital into AI suggests otherwise. While there may be some adjustments as the field matures, the broader trajectory of AI investment remains strong, driven by both immediate applications and longterm potential. In summary, while AIs development is complex and requires tempered expectations, dismissing the entire field as a bubble fails to appreciate the genuine advancements and ongoing potential that AI, particularly machine learning, continues to unlock.

Because they are investing in the next wave of labor replacements for the said trillions of future revenue? It turns out you need to invest now to see revenue later. You are also wrong about improvement costs being completely exponential. That is true for the scaling wide increasing parameter count and training time, but scaling vertically is much more efficient. I use the latest models every day for programming and it seems like every week theres something new that can solve some problems the previous model couldnt solve. The current state of the art is focused on improving training and making a corpus of training data have better results. The gains are spectacular. Microsofts Phi 3.5 mini came out last week and has 3.8B parameters. It outperforms Llama 2 70B from a year ago on benchmarks. Thats almost 20x less parameters and possibly training time. They did this by improving training methodology and making training data higher quality. So methodology is leading to huge improvements. Hyper scale companies are continuing to scale wide AND implement these methodologies. This means each generation is getting better and better and we have a while before we get to scraping the bottom of the barrel of the gains.

Sams talking about burning 50 billion a year to build AGI and its just got people wondering how many rounds well have to go on this before we get whats actually promised. At the end of the day its not his 50 billion to burn, his company isnt profitable so its gotta come from other people who arent going to keep ponying up if theres no progress to show for it. Obviously the AI sector is bigger than OpenAI, but theyre the best example. True AGI would be worth near infinite investment, but 400B for the current state of AI wasnt worth it, the longer this goes the more investors will just see it as throwing good money after bad.

The current existing robo taxis have tens of thousands of dollars of sensors on them and are geofenced to small mapped out areas. Tesla is selling their vehicles for less than the sensors alone on those vehicles and teslas will eventually have nongeofences full self driving. The calculations are being done in real time by AI trained on hundreds of thousands of hours of real time driving footage from real people. There is actually a literal vice premium built into the market for many stocks. Gambling, tobacco, etc., sometimes cantwont get touched by big institutional money managers, such as pension funds, for ethical reasons. Therefore, theres a smaller pool of buyers, and they trade more cheaply. So it works as a value play in some sense. But to outperform, you need that dynamic to go away and unlock more money in. Maybe you could argue that as societies mature, the definition of vice shrinks, and in 20 years, no one will care if you own tobacco stocks. Not sure I buy that, though.

Probably from their complete fuck ton of user chats call this user data, their nitro subscription, the fact that they are the best voice chat option available, it works better than Microsoft teams in every way and is becoming more popular every day. From tickernerd.com In the beginning, Discord was an instant messaging platform that initially targeted gamers but has since expanded to include various communities. The platform generates revenue through its freemium business model that offers a free version of its service and a paid version called Discord Nitro. Discord Nitro is a paid subscription that offers users enhanced features, such as higher resolution video, screen share, animated avatars, and custom emojis. Discord also generates revenue through server boosting which starts from 4.99 per month for Level 1 and costs up to 69.86 for Level 3. Server boosting is a way for users to upgrade a Discord server to have added perks and benefits such as better audio quality, larger upload limits, custom emoji slots, etc. Discord also partners with game developers who want to sell their products exclusively through the Discord platform. Discord earns a 10 commission on every game it sells, using its profits to reinvest back into the platform.
